05-26.description: On May 26, 1908, at Masjed Soleyman in southwest Persia, the first major commercial oil strike in the Middle East was made.

05-26.title: Last Model T Ford Produced
05-26.description: On May 26, 1927, Henry Ford and the Ford Motor Company produced the last (and 15 millionth) Model T Ford.

05-26.title: Apartheid Government Elected in South Africa
05-26.description: On May 26, 1948, South Africa elected a nationalist government under D. F. Malan with an apartheid policy.

05-26.title: Terry Nichols Convicted in Oklahoma City Bombing
05-26.description: On May 26, 2004, U.S. Army veteran Terry Nichols was found guilty of 161 state murder charges for helping carry out the Oklahoma City bombing.

05-27.title: Habeas Corpus Act Passes in England
05-27.description: On May 27, 1679, the Habeas Corpus Act passed in England, strengthening a person's right to challenge unlawful arrest and imprisonment.

05-27.title: Saint Petersburg Founded
05-27.description: On May 27, 1703, Saint Petersburg was founded by Russian Tsar Peter the Great.

05-27.title: Schliemann Discovers 'Priam's Treasure'
05-27.description: On May 27, 1873, Heinrich Schliemann discovered 'Priam's Treasure,' a cache of gold and other objects in Hisarlik (ancient Troy).

05-27.title: Battle of Tsushima
05-27.description: On May 27, 1905, the Japanese fleet destroyed the Russian East Sea fleet in the Battle of Tsushima, the only decisive clash between modern steel battleships in history.

05-27.title: Miracle of Dunkirk Begins
05-27.description: On May 27, 1940, British and Allied forces began the evacuation of Dunkirk (Operation Dynamo) during World War II.

05-27.title: Jomo Kenyatta Elected First Prime Minister of Kenya
05-27.description: On May 27, 1963, Jomo Kenyatta was elected as the first Prime Minister of a self-governing Kenya.

05-27.title: Slobodan Milošević Indicted for War Crimes
05-27.description: On May 27, 1999, the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia indicted Slobodan Milošević for war crimes committed in Kosovo.

05-27.title: Java Earthquake
05-27.description: On May 27, 2006, an earthquake struck Java, Indonesia, devastating the region and killing over 6,600 people.

05-28.title: Solar Eclipse Leads to Truce
05-28.description: On May 28, 585 BC, a solar eclipse, as predicted by Greek philosopher Thales, occurred during a battle between the Lydians and the Medes, leading to a truce.

05-28.title: Joan of Arc Accused of Relapsing into Heresy
05-28.description: On May 28, 1431, Joan of Arc was accused of relapsing into heresy by donning male clothing again, providing justification for her execution.

05-28.title: Spanish Armada Dispatched to Invade England
05-28.description: On May 28, 1588, King Philip II dispatched the Spanish Armada from Lisbon, Portugal to invade England.

05-28.title: President Jackson Signs Indian Removal Act
05-28.description: On May 28, 1830, US President Andrew Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act, a key law leading to the forced removal of Native American tribes.

05-28.title: Alan Turing Publishes 'On Computable Numbers'
05-28.description: On May 28, 1936, Alan Turing submitted 'On Computable Numbers' for publication, setting out the theoretical basis for modern computers.

05-28.title: First Watergate Break-in
05-28.description: On May 28, 1972, White House 'plumbers' first broke in at the Democratic National Headquarters and installed listening devices at the Watergate Complex.

05-29.title: Fall of Constantinople
05-29.description: On May 29, 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottoman Turks under Mehmed the Conqueror, ending the Byzantine Empire.

05-29.title: First Use of Korean Turtle Ship
05-29.description: On May 29, 1592, the Korean navy, led by Admiral Yi Sun-sin, repelled a Japanese fleet in the Battle of Sacheon, marking the first use of a Korean Turtle Ship.

05-29.title: Charles II Returns to Claim English Throne
05-29.description: On May 29, 1660, on his 30th birthday, Charles II returned to London from exile to claim the English throne after the Puritan Commonwealth came to an end.

05-29.title: Sojourner Truth Addresses Women's Rights Convention
05-29.description: On May 29, 1851, Sojourner Truth addressed the first Black Women's Rights Convention in Akron, Ohio.

05-29.title: First Ascent of Mount Everest
05-29.description: On May 29, 1953, Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay became the first to reach the summit of Mount Everest as part of a British expedition.

05-30.title: Joan of Arc Burned at the Stake
05-30.description: On May 30, 1431, 19-year-old Joan of Arc was burned at the stake by an English-dominated tribunal in Rouen, France.

05-30.title: Hernando de Soto's Expedition Lands in Florida
05-30.description: On May 30, 1539, Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto's expedition of 10 ships and 700 men landed in Florida.

05-30.title: Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo Comes into Force
05-30.description: On May 30, 1848, the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo between the United States and Mexico came into force, ceding large territories to the U.S. for $15 million.

05-30.title: Memorial Day First Observed
05-30.description: On May 30, 1868, 'Decoration Day,' later called Memorial Day, was first observed in Northern U.S. states.

05-30.title: Treaty of London Ends First Balkan War
05-30.description: On May 30, 1913, the Treaty of London was signed, bringing an end to the First Balkan War.

05-30.title: Hissène Habré Convicted of Crimes Against Humanity
05-30.description: On May 30, 2016, former Chadian dictator Hissène Habré was convicted of crimes against humanity by the Extraordinary African Chambers.

05-30.title: Donald Trump Found Guilty in Hush Money Trial
05-30.description: On May 30, 2024, a jury in New York City found former US President Donald Trump guilty on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.

05-31.title: Ramesses the Great Becomes Pharaoh
05-31.description: On May 31, 1279 BC, Ramesses II, also known as Ramesses the Great, became Pharaoh of Ancient Egypt's 19th Dynasty.

05-31.title: Martin Frobisher Sails for Canada
05-31.description: On May 31, 1578, Martin Frobisher sailed from Harwich, England, to Frobisher Bay, Canada. He eventually mined 'fools gold' famously used to pave London's streets.

05-31.title: Treaty of Vereeniging Ends Second Boer War
05-31.description: On May 31, 1902, the Treaty of Vereeniging was signed, ending the Second Boer War and making Transvaal and the Orange Free State self-governing British colonies.

05-31.title: Union of South Africa Declares Independence
05-31.description: On May 31, 1910, the Union of South Africa declared independence from the United Kingdom.

05-31.title: Battle of Jutland
05-31.description: On May 31, 1916, the Battle of Jutland, the largest naval battle of World War I, took place between the British and German fleets, resulting in a strategic British victory.

05-31.title: Quetta Earthquake
05-31.description: On May 31, 1935, a 7.7 magnitude earthquake destroyed Quetta in British India (now Pakistan), killing an estimated 40,000 people.

05-31.title: Communists Seize Power in Hungary
05-31.description: On May 31, 1947, Communists seized power in Hungary.

05-31.title: Ancash Earthquake in Peru
05-31.description: On May 31, 1970, a 7.75 magnitude Ancash earthquake off the coast of Peru killed up to 70,000 people and triggered the world's deadliest avalanche.

06-01.title: Hypothesized Domestication of the Horse
06-01.description: On June 1, 4000 BC, this is the approximate date for the domestication of the horse in the Eurasian steppes near Dereivka, central Ukraine (hypothesis only).

06-01.title: Mongols Capture and Loot Peking
06-01.description: On June 1, 1215, Peking (Beijing) was captured and looted for a month by the Mongols under Genghis Khan.

06-01.title: Andreas Vesalius Publishes Anatomy Book
06-01.description: On June 1, 1543, Flemish physician Andreas Vesalius published 'De humani corporis fabrica', a major step forward in understanding human anatomy.

06-01.title: Battle of Öland
06-01.description: On June 1, 1676, allied Danish-Dutch forces defeated the Swedish navy in the Baltic Sea during the Scanian War.

06-01.title: British Government Closes Port of Boston
06-01.description: On June 1, 1774, following the Boston Port Act, the British government ordered the Port of Boston closed to punish colonists for the Boston Tea Party.

06-01.title: European Central Bank Founded
06-01.description: On June 1, 1998, the European Central Bank was founded in Brussels to define and execute the European Union's monetary policy.

06-02.title: Vandals Sack Rome
06-02.description: On June 2, 455, King Gaiseric and the Vandals sacked Rome; the looting continued for 14 days.

06-02.title: Robert E. Lee Takes Command of Confederate Armies
06-02.description: On June 2, 1862, Robert E. Lee took command of the Confederate armies of North Virginia during the American Civil War.

06-02.title: Guglielmo Marconi Patents Wireless Telegraphy
06-02.description: On June 2, 1896, Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi applied for the first-ever patent for a system of wireless telegraphy in the United Kingdom.

06-02.title: Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II
06-02.description: On June 2, 1953, the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II took place in Westminster Abbey, London.

06-02.title: Tiananmen Square Protests Continue
06-02.description: On June 2, 1989, 10,000 Chinese soldiers were blocked by 100,000 citizens in Tiananmen Square, Beijing, protecting students demonstrating for democracy.

06-03.title: Dutch West India Company Chartered
06-03.description: On June 3, 1621, the Dutch West India Company received its charter for the West Indies (the Americas, Caribbean, and West Africa).

06-03.title: Treaty of Lima Signed
06-03.description: On June 3, 1929, Chile and Peru signed the Treaty of Lima, finally resolving their border dispute from the War of the Pacific.

06-03.title: Zoot Suit Riots Begin in Los Angeles
06-03.description: On June 3, 1943, a mob from the Los Angeles Naval Reserve Armory beat up everyone perceived to be Hispanic, starting the week-long Zoot Suit Riots.

06-03.title: Ixtoc I Oil Spill
06-03.description: On June 3, 1979, the Ixtoc I rig in the Gulf of Mexico blew out, spilling 3 million barrels of oil in one of the worst oil spills in history.

06-03.title: Tiananmen Square Massacre Begins
06-03.description: On June 3, 1989, the Tiananmen Square Massacre began as Chinese troops opened fire on pro-democracy supporters in Beijing.

06-04.title: New England Planters Arrive in Nova Scotia
06-04.description: On June 4, 1760, as part of the Great Upheaval, New England planters arrived in Nova Scotia, Canada, to claim land taken from the Acadians.

06-04.title: Miracle of Dunkirk Evacuation Completed
06-04.description: On June 4, 1940, the British completed the 'Miracle of Dunkirk' by evacuating 338,226 Allied troops from France.

06-04.title: Poland Holds First Partially Free Elections
06-04.description: On June 4, 1989, Eastern Europe's first partially free elections in 40 years were held in Poland, with the Solidarity Party coming to power.

06-04.title: Tiananmen Square Massacre
06-04.description: On June 4, 1989, Chinese troops cleared Tiananmen Square of student protesters; unofficial figures place the death toll near 1,000.

06-04.title: Ukrainian Counteroffensive Begins
06-04.description: On June 4, 2023, the Ukrainian counteroffensive began with increased fighting in the east and south of the country.

06-05.title: Zanzibar Slave Market Closed
06-05.description: On June 5, 1873, Sultan Barghash bin Said, under British pressure, closed the infamous slave market of Zanzibar in present-day Tanzania.

06-05.title: Marshall Plan Outlined
06-05.description: On June 5, 1947, US Secretary of State George Marshall outlined the 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild Western Europe.

06-05.title: Ayatollah Khomeini Arrested in Iran
06-05.description: On June 5, 1963, a state of siege was declared in Iran, and Ayatollah Khomeini was arrested.

06-05.title: Six-Day War Begins
06-05.description: On June 5, 1967, the Six-Day War began between Israel and the neighboring Arab states of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.

06-05.title: Robert F. Kennedy Assassinated
06-05.description: On June 5, 1968, Palestinian Sirhan Sirhan assassinated Robert F. Kennedy at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. Kennedy died the next day.

06-05.title: AIDS Epidemic Officially Begins
06-05.description: On June 5, 1981, the AIDS epidemic officially began when the US Centers for Disease Control reported on a rare pneumonia affecting five homosexual men in Los Angeles.

06-05.title: Indian Army Attacks Golden Temple
06-05.description: On June 5, 1984, Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered an attack on Sikhism's holiest site, the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

06-06.title: Gustav Vasa Elected King of Sweden
06-06.description: On June 6, 1523, Gustav Vasa was elected King of Sweden, marking the end of the Kalmar Union.

06-06.title: First African Slaves Transported to Louisiana
06-06.description: On June 6, 1716, the French transported the first African slaves to Louisiana.

06-06.title: Death of Yuan Shikai
06-06.description: On June 6, 1916, the death of Yuan Shikai, ruler of much of China, caused the central government to virtually collapse in the face of pressure from warlords.

06-06.title: D-Day: Allied Invasion of Normandy
06-06.description: On June 6, 1944, Operation Overlord began as the 156,000-strong Allied Expeditionary Force landed in Normandy, France, during World War II.

06-06.title: Israel Invades Lebanon
06-06.description: On June 6, 1982, 30,000 Israeli troops invaded Lebanon to drive out the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO).

06-07.title: Treaty of Tordesillas Signed
06-07.description: On June 7, 1494, the Treaty of Tordesillas was signed, where Spain and Portugal agreed to divide the New World between them.

06-07.title: King Charles I Ratifies Petition of Right
06-07.description: On June 7, 1628, English King Charles I ratified the Petition of Right, a statement of civil liberties.

06-07.title: Louis XIV Crowned King of France
06-07.description: On June 7, 1654, Louis XIV was crowned King of France.

06-07.title: British Museum Founded
06-07.description: On June 7, 1753, the British Museum was founded by an Act of Parliament with royal assent from King George II.

06-07.title: Vatican City Becomes a Sovereign State
06-07.description: On June 7, 1929, Vatican City became a sovereign state through the Lateran Treaty.

06-07.title: Griswold v. Connecticut Legalizes Contraception for Married Couples
06-07.description: On June 7, 1965, the Supreme Court of the United States decided on Griswold v. Connecticut, effectively legalizing the use of contraception by married couples.

06-08.title: Attila the Hun Invades Italy
06-08.description: On June 8, 452, Attila the Hun invaded Italy.

06-08.title: First Recorded Viking Raid on England
06-08.description: On June 8, 793, Vikings plundered the monastery on Lindisfarne Island off the coast of England, capturing and killing monks.

06-08.title: Richard I Arrives at Acre for Third Crusade
06-08.description: On June 8, 1191, King Richard I of England arrived at Acre in modern-day Israel to join the siege during the Third Crusade.

06-08.title: Laki Volcano Erupts in Iceland
06-08.description: On June 8, 1783, the Laki volcano in southern Iceland began an 8-month eruption, killing 10,000 people and causing widespread famine.

06-08.title: James Madison Introduces Bill of Rights
06-08.description: On June 8, 1789, James Madison introduced a proposed Bill of Rights in the U.S. House of Representatives.

06-08.title: Brightest Nova Since 1604 Discovered
06-08.description: On June 8, 1918, Nova Aquilae was discovered, the brightest nova since Kepler's nova of 1604.

06-08.title: New Zealand Legislates Against Nuclear Weapons
06-08.description: On June 8, 1987, New Zealand's Labour government passed legislation against nuclear weapons and nuclear-powered vessels.

06-09.title: Roman Emperor Nero Commits Suicide
06-09.description: On June 9, 68, Roman Emperor Nero committed suicide, imploring his secretary to slit his throat.

06-09.title: Muslim Expansion in Western Europe Halted
06-09.description: On June 9, 721, Odo of Aquitaine defeated a Umayyad Muslim army at the Battle of Toulouse, halting Arab expansion in Western Europe.

06-09.title: Book of Common Prayer Adopted
06-09.description: On June 9, 1549, the Book of Common Prayer was adopted by the Church of England.

06-09.title: Congress of Vienna Ends
06-09.description: On June 9, 1815, the Congress of Vienna ended after reshaping the political map of Europe following the Napoleonic Wars.

06-09.title: Mormons Begin Handcart Journey West
06-09.description: On June 9, 1856, a group of Mormons left Iowa City, Iowa, and headed west for Salt Lake City, Utah, carrying their possessions in two-wheeled handcarts.

06-09.title: China Leases Hong Kong's New Territories to Britain
06-09.description: On June 9, 1898, China leased Hong Kong's New Territories to the United Kingdom for 99 years.

06-09.title: Massive Protests in Hong Kong
06-09.description: On June 9, 2019, over 1 million people protested in Hong Kong against proposed new laws for extradition to China.

06-10.title: Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa Drowns
06-10.description: On June 10, 1190, Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa drowned while crossing a river, leading an army to Jerusalem during the Third Crusade.

06-10.title: Landslide Dam Collapse in China Kills 100,000
06-10.description: On June 10, 1786, a landslide dam on the Dadu River collapsed, killing 100,000 in Sichuan province, China.

06-10.title: U.S. Marines Land in Cuba
06-10.description: On June 10, 1898, U.S. Marines landed in Cuba during the Spanish–American War.

06-10.title: Great Arab Revolt Begins
06-10.description: On June 10, 1916, Hashemite-led Arabs of the Hejaz rose up against the ruling Ottoman Empire in the Great Arab Revolt of World War I.

06-10.title: U.S. Equal Pay Act Signed
06-10.description: On June 10, 1963, the U.S. Equal Pay Act was signed into law by President John F. Kennedy.

06-10.title: First Apple II Computers Shipped
06-10.description: On June 10, 1977, Apple Computer shipped its first Apple II computers.

06-10.title: Spirit Rover Launched to Mars
06-10.description: On June 10, 2003, the Spirit Rover was launched, beginning NASA's Mars Exploration Rover mission.

06-11.title: Traditional Date for the Sacking of Troy
06-11.description: On June 11, 1184 BC, Troy was sacked and burned according to calculations by Eratosthenes.

06-11.title: Emperor Taizong Frees 80,000 Chinese Prisoners
06-11.description: On June 11, 631, Emperor Taizong of Tang sent envoys with gold and silk to the Xueyantuo, succeeding in freeing 80,000 captured Chinese prisoners.

06-11.title: Committee to Draft Declaration of Independence Formed
06-11.description: On June 11, 1776, the Continental Congress created a committee to draft a Declaration of Independence with Thomas Jefferson and John Adams among its members.

06-11.title: JFK Condemns Segregation
06-11.description: On June 11, 1963, US President John F. Kennedy said segregation was morally wrong and that it was 'time to act'.

06-11.title: Margaret Thatcher Wins Third Term
06-11.description: On June 11, 1987, Margaret Thatcher became the first British Prime Minister in 160 years to win a third consecutive term.

06-11.title: H1N1 Swine Flu Declared a Global Pandemic
06-11.description: On June 11, 2009, the World Health Organization declared H1N1 swine flu to be a global pandemic.

06-11.title: ISIS Seizes Control of Mosul
06-11.description: On June 11, 2014, Islamic State of Iraq forces seized control of government offices and other important buildings in the northern city of Mosul.

06-12.title: Spinning Jenny Patented
06-12.description: On June 12, 1770, a patent for the 'Spinning Jenny', the first multiple spinning machine, was granted to English weaver James Hargreaves.

06-12.title: French Colonization of Algeria Begins
06-12.description: On June 12, 1830, 34,000 French soldiers landed near Algiers, beginning the French colonization of Algeria.

06-12.title: Battle of Trevilian Station
06-12.description: On June 12, 1864, the Battle of Trevilian Station, the bloodiest and largest all-cavalry battle of the American Civil War, ended in a Confederate tactical victory.

06-12.title: Al Capone Indicted for Prohibition Violations
06-12.description: On June 12, 1931, Al Capone was indicted on 5,000 counts of prohibition violations and perjury.

06-12.title: Anne Frank Receives Her Diary
06-12.description: On June 12, 1942, Anne Frank received her diary as a birthday present in Amsterdam.

06-12.title: Nelson Mandela Sentenced to Life in Prison
06-12.description: On June 12, 1964, Nelson Mandela was sentenced to life in prison for sabotage in South Africa.

06-12.title: Boris Yeltsin Wins Russia's First Presidential Election
06-12.description: On June 12, 1991, Boris Yeltsin won Russia's first presidential election with 57% of the vote.

06-12.title: Trump and Kim Jong-un Meet in Singapore
06-12.description: On June 12, 2018, the Singapore Summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and US President Donald Trump marked the first time leaders of the two nations had met.

06-13.title: Anglo-Portuguese Treaty Signed
06-13.description: On June 13, 1373, the Anglo-Portuguese Treaty of Perpetual Alliance, the world's oldest still in existence, was signed in London.

06-13.title: U.S. House Passes 14th Amendment
06-13.description: On June 13, 1866, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the 14th Amendment (Civil Rights).

06-13.title: Congress of Berlin Begins
06-13.description: On June 13, 1878, the Congress of Berlin began, to determine the territories of the states in the Balkan peninsula following the Russo-Turkish War.

06-13.title: Last British Troops Leave Suez Canal Zone
06-13.description: On June 13, 1956, the last British troops left the Suez Canal Zone in Egypt.

06-13.title: First Inter-Korean Summit
06-13.description: On June 13, 2000, South Korean President Kim Dae-jung met North Korean leader Kim Jong-il for the first-ever inter-Korean summit in Pyongyang.

06-14.title: Peasants' Revolt Reaches London
06-14.description: On June 14, 1381, Richard II met leaders of the Peasants' Revolt. The Tower of London was stormed by rebels who entered without resistance.

06-14.title: Battle of Naseby
06-14.description: On June 14, 1645, Parliament's New Model Army under Oliver Cromwell defeated the Royalist forces of King Charles I at the Battle of Naseby.

06-14.title: Continental Congress Adopts Stars & Stripes Flag
06-14.description: On June 14, 1777, the U.S. Continental Congress adopted the Stars & Stripes flag, replacing the Grand Union flag.

06-14.title: Kingdom of Sennar Ends
06-14.description: On June 14, 1821, the King of Sennar surrendered his throne to forces of the Ottoman Empire, bringing the 300-year-old Sudanese kingdom to an end.

06-14.title: Auschwitz Concentration Camp Opens
06-14.description: On June 14, 1940, Auschwitz concentration and extermination camp opened in Nazi-controlled Poland. At least 1.1 million would die within its walls.

06-14.title: Mass Deportations from Estonia
06-14.description: On June 14, 1941, Estonia lost 11,000 inhabitants as a consequence of mass deportations into Siberia by the Soviet Union.

06-14.title: Argentina Surrenders in Falklands War
06-14.description: On June 14, 1982, Argentina surrendered to the United Kingdom, ending the 74-day Falklands War.

06-15.title: Assyrian Solar Eclipse Recorded
06-15.description: On June 15, 763 BC, Assyrians recorded a solar eclipse that would later be used to fix the chronology of Mesopotamian history.

06-15.title: King John Signs the Magna Carta
06-15.description: On June 15, 1215, King John of England signed the Magna Carta at Runnymede, limiting royal authority and establishing that the king is not above the law.

06-15.title: Dannebrog, World's Oldest National Flag, Legend
06-15.description: On June 15, 1219, according to legend, the Dannebrog, the flag of Denmark, fell from the sky during the Battle of Lyndanisse and turned the Danes' luck.

06-15.title: Battle of Kosovo
06-15.description: On June 15, 1389, the Ottomans defeated the Serbian army in the bloody Battle of Kosovo, opening the way for the Ottoman conquest of Southeastern Europe.

06-15.title: George Washington Appointed Commander-in-Chief
06-15.description: On June 15, 1775, George Washington was appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army.

06-15.title: Tsunami Strikes Sanriku, Japan
06-15.description: On June 15, 1896, a tsunami struck a Shinto festival on the beach at Sanriku, Japan, killing 27,000 people.

06-15.title: German Troops Occupy Paris
06-15.description: On June 15, 1940, German troops occupied Paris as French resistance to the German invasion crumbled.

06-15.title: Mount Pinatubo Erupts
06-15.description: On June 15, 1991, the climactic eruption of Mount Pinatubo occurred in the Philippines, the second-largest volcanic eruption on Earth in the 20th century.

06-16.title: Spain Declares War on Great Britain
06-16.description: On June 16, 1779, Spain declared war on Great Britain in support of France and the USA, starting the Great Siege of Gibraltar.

06-16.title: Lincoln's 'House Divided' Speech
06-16.description: On June 16, 1858, Abraham Lincoln said 'A house divided against itself cannot stand' when accepting the Illinois Republican Party's nomination for the Senate.

06-16.title: Bloomsday
06-16.description: June 16, 1904, is known as Bloomsday, the date on which the fictional events in James Joyce's novel 'Ulysses' take place.

06-16.title: First Woman in Space
06-16.description: On June 16, 1963, Soviet space mission Vostok 6 was launched with Valentina Tereshkova onboard, who became the first woman in space.

06-16.title: Israel Withdraws from Lebanon
06-16.description: On June 16, 2000, Israel complied with UN Security Council Resolution 425 after 22 years, which called on Israel to completely withdraw from Lebanon.

06-17.title: First Caliph of Rashidun Caliphate Elected
06-17.description: On June 17, 656, Ali ibn Abu Talib was elected the 4th Caliph of the Rashidun Caliphate.

06-17.title: Narváez Expedition Departs for Florida
06-17.description: On June 17, 1527, Pánfilo de Narváez departed Spain to explore Florida with five ships and 600 men; by 1536, only four men were still alive.

06-17.title: Francis Drake Lands in California
06-17.description: On June 17, 1579, English navigator Francis Drake landed on the coast of California at Drakes Bay for ship repairs and claimed the area for Queen Elizabeth.

06-17.title: Mumtaz Mahal Dies, Inspiring the Taj Mahal
06-17.description: On June 17, 1631, Mumtaz Mahal died during childbirth. Her husband, Mughal emperor Shah Jahan I, then spent more than 20 years building her tomb, the Taj Mahal.

06-17.title: Third Estate Proclaims Itself National Assembly
06-17.description: On June 17, 1789, during the French Revolution, the Third Estate proclaimed itself the 'National Assembly'.

06-17.title: Charles Goodyear Obtains Rubber Patent
06-17.description: On June 17, 1837, Charles Goodyear obtained his first patent for vulcanized rubber.

06-17.title: First Republican National Convention
06-17.description: On June 17, 1856, the Republican Party opened its first national convention in Philadelphia.

06-18.title: Tang Dynasty Rule Begins in China
06-18.description: On June 18, 618, Li Yuan was coronated as Emperor Gaozu of Tang, initiating three centuries of Tang Dynasty rule over China.

06-18.title: War of 1812 Begins
06-18.description: On June 18, 1812, the War of 1812 began when the U.S. declared war against Great Britain.

06-18.title: Battle of Waterloo
06-18.description: On June 18, 1815, Napoleon Bonaparte and France were defeated by British and Prussian forces at the Battle of Waterloo.

06-18.title: Amelia Earhart Crosses the Atlantic
06-18.description: On June 18, 1928, American aviator Amelia Earhart became the first woman to fly across the Atlantic Ocean (as a passenger).

06-18.title: Churchill's 'Finest Hour' Speech
06-18.description: On June 18, 1940, Winston Churchill gave his 'This was their finest hour' speech to the House of Commons, urging perseverance in the war.

06-19.title: Battle of Methven
06-19.description: On June 19, 1306, the Earl of Pembroke's army defeated Robert the Bruce's Scottish army at the Battle of Methven.

06-19.title: London's Metropolitan Police Act Introduced
06-19.description: On June 19, 1829, Robert Peel introduced the Metropolitan Police Act 1829 into Parliament to establish a unified police force for London.

06-19.title: Slavery Outlawed in U.S. Territories
06-19.description: On June 19, 1862, slavery was outlawed in U.S. territories.

06-19.title: Juneteenth: Slavery Ends in Texas
06-19.description: On June 19, 1865, Union General Gordon Granger declared slaves free in Texas. The date is now celebrated across the U.S. as Juneteenth.

06-19.title: Battle of the Philippine Sea
06-19.description: On June 19, 1944, the two-day Battle of the Philippine Sea began, in which U.S. naval forces defeated the Japanese fleet.

06-19.title: Pablo Escobar Surrenders
06-19.description: On June 19, 1991, Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar surrendered to police.

06-20.title: Battle of the Catalaunian Plains
06-20.description: On June 20, 451, Roman and Visigoth forces defeated Attila the Hun in northeast France, halting the Hun invasion of Roman Gaul.

06-20.title: Tennis Court Oath
06-20.description: On June 20, 1789, during the French Revolution, the Third Estate swore the Tennis Court Oath, vowing not to disband until a new constitution was formed.

06-20.title: Samuel Morse Patents Telegraph
06-20.description: On June 20, 1840, American inventor Samuel Morse patented his telegraph.

06-20.title: First Woman Earns Physics PhD in America
06-20.description: On June 20, 1895, Caroline Willard Baldwin became the first woman to earn a PhD in Physics from an American university, receiving her degree from Cornell.

06-20.title: Highest Temperature Recorded in Arctic Circle
06-20.description: On June 20, 2020, the highest-ever temperature was recorded in the Arctic Circle: 38°C (100°F) in Verkhoyansk, Siberia.

06-21.title: U.S. Constitution Comes into Effect
06-21.description: On June 21, 1788, the U.S. Constitution came into effect when New Hampshire became the 9th state to ratify it.

06-21.title: First Victoria Cross Awarded
06-21.description: On June 21, 1854, the first Victoria Cross was won during the bombardment of Bomarsund in the Åland Islands during the Crimean War.

06-21.title: Columbia Records Unveils the LP
06-21.description: On June 21, 1948, Columbia Records unveiled the 33-1/3 rpm LP phonograph record, allowing up to 20 minutes of music per side.

06-21.title: Lord Mountbatten Resigns as Governor General of India
06-21.description: On June 21, 1948, Lord Mountbatten resigned as the first Governor General of India (formerly the last Viceroy).

06-21.title: Manjil-Rudbar Earthquake in Iran
06-21.description: On June 21, 1990, the 7.7 magnitude Manjil-Rudbar Earthquake hit Iran, killing between 35,000 and 50,000 people.

06-21.title: Fermat's Last Theorem Proven
06-21.description: On June 21, 1993, English mathematician Andrew Wiles announced his proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, solving one of the world's most difficult math problems.

06-22.title: Galileo Galilei Recants Heliocentric Position
06-22.description: On June 22, 1633, Galileo Galilei was forced by the Roman Catholic Inquisition to recant his 'heretical' position that the Earth orbits the Sun.

06-22.title: Royal Greenwich Observatory Established
06-22.description: On June 22, 1675, the Royal Greenwich Observatory was established in England by King Charles II.

06-22.title: Somerset Case Boosts Abolitionist Movement
06-22.description: On June 22, 1772, the Somerset v Stewart court case found slavery was unsupported by English common law, encouraging the abolitionist movement.

06-22.title: June Days Uprising Begins in Paris
06-22.description: On June 22, 1848, the June Days uprising began in Paris, an insurrection staged by French workers.

06-22.title: Last Shot of the American Civil War
06-22.description: On June 22, 1865, the CSS Shenandoah fired the last shot of the American Civil War in the Bering Strait.

06-22.title: Germany Invades the Soviet Union
06-22.description: On June 22, 1941, Nazi Germany launched Operation Barbarossa, invading the Soviet Union in the largest military operation in history.

06-23.title: World's Oldest Parliament Established
06-23.description: On June 23, 930, the world's oldest parliament, the Icelandic Althing, was established.

06-23.title: First Commercially Successful Typewriter Patented
06-23.description: On June 23, 1868, Christopher Latham Sholes patented the Sholes and Glidden typewriter, featuring the QWERTY keyboard layout.

06-23.title: First Contraceptive Pill Available in U.S.
06-23.description: On June 23, 1960, the first contraceptive pill was made available for purchase in the United States.

06-23.title: Hurricane Agnes Becomes America's Costliest Disaster
06-23.description: On June 23, 1972, Hurricane Agnes became America's costliest natural disaster at the time, with 119 deaths and $3 billion in damage.

06-23.title: Lech Wałęsa Meets Pope John Paul II
06-23.description: On June 23, 1983, Solidarity leader Lech Wałęsa met Pope John Paul II during the Pope's visit to Poland.

06-23.title: United Kingdom Votes for Brexit
06-23.description: On June 23, 2016, the United Kingdom voted in the Brexit referendum to leave the European Union.

06-24.title: John Cabot Claims North America for England
06-24.description: On June 24, 1497, John Cabot claimed parts of North America (in what is now Eastern Canada) for England, believing he had found Asia.

06-24.title: Henry VIII Crowned King of England
06-24.description: On June 24, 1509, Henry VIII was crowned King of England in Westminster Abbey, London.

06-24.title: Napoleon Invades Russia
06-24.description: On June 24, 1812, Napoleon Bonaparte's Grand Armée, numbering half a million, began its invasion of Russia by crossing the Nieman River.

06-24.title: Gadsden Purchase Signed
06-24.description: On June 24, 1853, US President Franklin Pierce signed the Gadsden Purchase, buying 29,670 square miles from Mexico for $10 million.

06-24.title: Precursor to Radar First Demonstrated
06-24.description: On June 24, 1930, the first detection of an airplane using reflected radio waves, a precursor to radar, was achieved by U.S. Naval Research Laboratory engineers.

06-24.title: Berlin Blockade Begins
06-24.description: On June 24, 1948, the Soviet Union blockaded West Berlin by stopping access by road, rail, and water, leading to the Berlin Airlift.

06-24.title: U.S. Supreme Court Overturns Roe v. Wade
06-24.description: On June 24, 2022, the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion in a 6-3 vote.

06-25.title: First Woman to Receive a University PhD
06-25.description: On June 25, 1678, Venetian Elena Cornaro Piscopia was awarded a doctorate of philosophy from the University of Padua, the first woman to receive a PhD.

06-25.title: Custer's Last Stand
06-25.description: On June 25, 1876, at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, the U.S. 7th Cavalry under George Armstrong Custer was wiped out by Sioux and Cheyenne warriors.

06-25.title: Hoover Dam Construction Authorized
06-25.description: On June 25, 1929, US President Herbert Hoover authorized the building of Boulder Dam (now Hoover Dam).

06-25.title: FDR Forbids Racial Discrimination in Defense Industry
06-25.description: On June 25, 1941, US President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Executive Order 8802, which forbade racial discrimination in the defense industry.

06-25.title: Korean War Begins
06-25.description: On June 25, 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea, beginning the Korean War.

06-25.title: WHO Confirms Transmissibility of COVID-19 Delta Variant
06-25.description: On June 25, 2021, the WHO confirmed the COVID-19 Delta variant as the most transmissible to date, present in 85 countries.

06-26.title: Roman Emperor Julian Killed
06-26.description: On June 26, 363, Roman Emperor Julian was killed during a retreat from the Sassanid Empire. General Jovian was proclaimed Emperor by the troops.

06-26.title: Battle of Fleurus
06-26.description: On June 26, 1794, at the Battle of Fleurus, French forces defeated the Coalition Army with the first military use of a reconnaissance balloon.

06-26.title: First Victoria Crosses Awarded
06-26.description: On June 26, 1857, the first 62 recipients received the Victoria Cross for valor in the Crimean War from Queen Victoria.

06-26.title: First U.S. Troops Arrive in France for WWI
06-26.description: On June 26, 1917, the first U.S. troops arrived in France during World War I.

06-26.title: United Nations Charter Signed
06-26.description: On June 26, 1945, the United Nations Charter was signed by 50 nations in San Francisco.

06-26.title: Panama Canal Expansion Opens
06-26.description: On June 26, 2016, the Panama Canal's third set of locks opened for commercial traffic, doubling the Canal’s capacity.

06-27.title: First European Voyage to Explore West Coast of North America
06-27.description: On June 27, 1542, Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo set sail from Mexico on the first European voyage to explore the west coast of North America.

06-27.title: Battle of Poltava
06-27.description: On June 27, 1709, Peter the Great of Russia defeated Charles XII of Sweden at the Battle of Poltava during the Great Northern War.

06-27.title: Battle of Dettingen
06-27.description: On June 27, 1743, King George II of Britain personally led Allied troops to victory in the Battle of Dettingen. It was the last time a British monarch commanded troops in the field.

06-27.title: Mutiny on the Battleship Potemkin
06-27.description: On June 27, 1905, Russian sailors mutinied aboard the battleship 'Potemkin' and sailed for Odessa.

06-27.title: First-Ever Aerial Refueling
06-27.description: On June 27, 1923, Capt. Lowell H. Smith and Lt. John P. Richter performed the first-ever aerial refueling in a DH-4B biplane.

06-27.title: Korean War: Truman Orders U.S. Forces into Conflict
06-27.description: On June 27, 1950, after North Korean troops reached Seoul, President Truman ordered the U.S. Air Force and Navy into the Korean conflict.

06-27.title: First Nuclear Power Station Opens
06-27.description: On June 27, 1954, the world's first nuclear power station to generate electricity for a power grid opened in Obninsk, near Moscow, Russia.

06-28.title: Charles V Elected Holy Roman Emperor
06-28.description: On June 28, 1519, King Carlos I of Spain was elected Holy Roman Emperor Charles V.

06-28.title: Coronation of Queen Victoria
06-28.description: On June 28, 1838, the coronation of Queen Victoria, aged 19, took place during a five-hour ceremony at Westminster Abbey.

06-28.title: Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand
06-28.description: On June 28, 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Sophie were assassinated in Sarajevo, setting off a chain of events that led to World War I.

06-28.title: Treaty of Versailles Signed
06-28.description: On June 28, 1919, the Treaty of Versailles was signed in France, formally ending World War I and establishing the League of Nations.

06-28.title: Tigrayan Forces Retake Mekelle
06-28.description: On June 28, 2021, Tigray Defense Forces retook Tigray's regional capital of Mekelle in Ethiopia's Tigray War.

06-29.title: Shakespeare's Globe Theatre Burns Down
06-29.description: On June 29, 1613, Shakespeare's Globe Theatre in London burned down during a performance of 'Henry VIII'.

06-29.title: Chinese Court Issues Anti-Foreigner Decree
06-29.description: On June 29, 1900, during the Boxer Rebellion, the Imperial Chinese Court issued what was essentially a declaration of war against foreigners in China.

06-29.title: Ford-Ferguson 9N Tractor Introduced
06-29.description: On June 29, 1939, Ford introduced the revolutionary Ford-Ferguson 9N tractor incorporating Harry Ferguson's three-point hitch system.

06-29.title: Bucharest Pogrom
06-29.description: On June 29, 1941, approximately 6,000 Jews were murdered in a pogrom in Bucharest, Romania.

06-29.title: Civil Rights Act of 1964 Passes U.S. Senate
06-29.description: On June 29, 1964, the Civil Rights Act of 1964 passed the U.S. Senate after a 60-working-day filibuster by Southern senators.

06-29.title: U.S. Bombs Hanoi and Haiphong
06-29.description: On June 29, 1966, U.S. planes bombed North Vietnam's capital, Hanoi, and the port city of Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.

06-29.title: U.S. Reopens Guantanamo Bay for Refugees
06-29.description: On June 29, 1994, the U.S. reopened Guantanamo Naval Base to process refugees.

06-30.title: Spanish Conquistadors Expelled from Tenochtitlan
06-30.description: On June 30, 1520, Spanish conquistadors were expelled from Tenochtitlan following an Aztec revolt during 'La Noche Triste' (the Night of Sadness).

06-30.title: Oxford Evolution Debate
06-30.description: On June 30, 1860, a famous debate on Charles Darwin's theory of evolution was held at the Oxford University Museum.

06-30.title: Battleship Potemkin Arrives in Odessa
06-30.description: On June 30, 1905, the mutinous battleship Potemkin arrived in Odessa, where sailors joined civilians in revolutionary actions.

06-30.title: Tunguska Event
06-30.description: On June 30, 1908, a giant fireball, likely a meteoroid, flattened 80 million trees near the Stony Tunguska River in Russia in the largest impact event in recorded history.

06-30.title: Night of the Long Knives
06-30.description: On June 30, 1934, Adolf Hitler staged a bloody purge of the Nazi party in the 'Night of the Long Knives'.

06-30.title: British Lease on Hong Kong's New Territories Expires
06-30.description: On June 30, 1997, the British lease on the New Territories in Hong Kong expired, preceding the handover of sovereignty to China.

07-01.title: Battle of the Boyne
07-01.description: On July 1, 1690, the army of Protestant King William III defeated deposed Roman Catholic King James II in the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland.

07-01.title: Darwin and Wallace's Papers on Evolution Presented
07-01.description: On July 1, 1858, papers on evolution by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace were jointly read to the Linnean Society of London.

07-01.title: Battle of Gettysburg Begins
07-01.description: On July 1, 1863, the Battle of Gettysburg began in Pennsylvania, where Union forces halted Confederate General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia.

07-01.title: Dominion of Canada Formed
07-01.description: On July 1, 1867, the Dominion of Canada was formed, comprising the provinces of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Ontario and Quebec.

07-01.title: First Day of the Battle of the Somme
07-01.description: On July 1, 1916, the first day of the Battle of the Somme, the British Army suffered its worst day in history, losing 19,240 men.

07-01.title: Hong Kong Handed Over to China
07-01.description: On July 1, 1997, the United Kingdom returned sovereignty over Hong Kong and the New Territories to the People's Republic of China.

07-02.title: Incident at Xuanwu Gate
07-02.description: On July 2, 626, Prince Li Shimin of the Tang Dynasty ambushed and killed his rival brothers, securing his path to the throne.

07-02.title: Continental Congress Declares Independence
07-02.description: On July 2, 1776, the Continental Congress resolved that 'these United Colonies are, and of right ought to be Free and Independent States'.

07-02.title: Bahia Independence Day in Brazil
07-02.description: On July 2, 1823, the end of Portuguese rule in Brazil was secured with the final defeat of Portuguese loyalists in the province of Bahia.

07-02.title: The Salvation Army Founded
07-02.description: On July 2, 1865, William and Catherine Booth founded the East London Christian Mission, now known as The Salvation Army.

07-02.title: Civil Rights Act of 1964 Signed
07-02.description: On July 2, 1964, US President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act into law.

07-02.title: Mecca Tunnel Tragedy
07-02.description: On July 2, 1990, 1,426 pilgrims were trampled to death after a panic in a pedestrian tunnel in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.

07-03.title: Battle of Adrianople
07-03.description: On July 3, 324, Roman Emperor Constantine I defeated his co-emperor Licinius at the Battle of Adrianople.

07-03.title: Battle of Gettysburg Ends
07-03.description: On July 3, 1863, the Battle of Gettysburg ended in a major victory for the Union during the US Civil War.

07-03.title: First Dow Jones Stock Index Published
07-03.description: On July 3, 1884, Dow Jones published its first stock index, the Dow Jones Transportation Average.

07-03.title: Stone of Scone Returned to Scotland
07-03.description: On July 3, 1996, the UK House of Commons announced that the Stone of Scone would be returned to Scotland after 700 years in Westminster Abbey.

07-04.title: U.S. Declaration of Independence
07-04.description: On July 4, 1776, the U.S. Congress proclaimed the Declaration of Independence from Great Britain.

07-04.title: James Hutton Presents Theory of Uniformitarianism
07-04.description: On July 4, 1785, geologist James Hutton publicly read an abstract of his theory of uniformitarianism for the first time.

07-04.title: Louisiana Purchase Announced
07-04.description: On July 4, 1803, the Louisiana Purchase was announced to the American people by President Thomas Jefferson.

07-04.title: Huskar Pit Disaster
07-04.description: On July 4, 1838, 26 children drowned while trying to escape flooding in a coal mine in England, leading to the 1842 Mines Act.

07-04.title: Atomic Bomb Chain-Reaction Design Patented
07-04.description: On July 4, 1934, Hungarian physicist Leó Szilárd patented the chain-reaction design for the atomic bomb.

07-04.title: North Korea Tests First ICBM
07-04.description: On July 4, 2017, North Korea test-fired its first successful intercontinental ballistic missile into the Sea of Japan.

07-05.title: Isaac Newton's 'Principia' Published
07-05.description: On July 5, 1687, Isaac Newton's great work, 'Principia Mathematica,' was published, outlining his laws of motion and universal gravitation.

07-05.title: Venezuela Declares Independence
07-05.description: On July 5, 1811, seven Venezuelan provinces declared their independence from Spain.

07-05.title: Frederick Douglass's 'Fourth of July' Speech
07-05.description: On July 5, 1852, Frederick Douglass delivered his 'What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?' speech, condemning the celebration as a hypocritical sham.

07-05.title: U.S. Secret Service Begins Operation
07-05.description: On July 5, 1865, the U.S. Secret Service began operating under the Treasury Department.

07-05.title: Amazon.com Founded
07-05.description: On July 5, 1994, Amazon.com was founded by Jeff Bezos in Bellevue, Washington.

07-05.title: First Direct Presidential Election in Indonesia
07-05.description: On July 5, 2004, the first direct presidential election was held in Indonesia.

07-06.title: Papal Bull Defends Jews During Black Death
07-06.description: On July 6, 1348, a papal bull from Pope Clement VI, issued during the Black Death, stated that Jews were not to blame and encouraged their protection.

07-06.title: Congress Issues 'Declaration of the Causes'
07-06.description: On July 6, 1775, the Continental Congress issued the 'Declaration of the Causes and Necessity of Taking up Arms'.

07-06.title: U.S. Dollar Adopted as Currency
07-06.description: On July 6, 1785, the U.S. Congress unanimously resolved to name the U.S. currency the 'dollar' and adopted decimal coinage.

07-06.title: Louis Pasteur Successfully Tests Rabies Vaccine
07-06.description: On July 6, 1885, Louis Pasteur successfully gave an anti-rabies vaccine to 9-year-old Joseph Meister, saving his life.

07-06.title: Soviet Union Formally Established
07-06.description: On July 6, 1923, the Russian Empire formally became the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR).

07-06.title: Nigerian Civil War Erupts
07-06.description: On July 6, 1967, the Nigerian Civil War erupted as Nigerian forces invaded the secessionist state of Biafra.

07-06.title: First No-Fault Divorce Law in U.S.
07-06.description: On July 6, 1970, California passed the first no-fault divorce law in the United States.

07-07.title: Battle of Otumba
07-07.description: On July 7, 1520, Hernán Cortés and his Tlaxcalan allies defeated a numerically superior Aztec force in the Battle of Otumba in Mexico.

07-07.title: First Treaty of Tilsit Signed
07-07.description: On July 7, 1807, French Emperor Napoléon Bonaparte and Russian Tsar Alexander I met on a raft and signed the first Treaty of Tilsit.

07-07.title: Second Sino-Japanese War Begins
07-07.description: On July 7, 1937, Japanese and Chinese troops clashed at the Marco Polo Bridge near Beijing, beginning the Second Sino-Japanese War.

07-07.title: Roswell UFO Incident
07-07.description: July 7, 1947, is the date associated with the alleged and disputed UFO incident in Roswell, New Mexico.

07-07.title: London Terrorist Bombings
07-07.description: On July 7, 2005, coordinated terrorist bomb blasts struck London's public transport system, killing 52 and injuring 700.

07-07.title: G8 Leaders Pledge Aid to Africa
07-07.description: On July 7, 2005, influenced by global Live 8 concerts, G8 leaders pledged to double aid to Africa and drop the debt of 18 of the poorest countries.

07-08.title: First Crusade Marches on Jerusalem
07-08.description: On July 8, 1099, during the First Crusade, 15,000 starving Christian soldiers marched in a religious procession around Jerusalem.

07-08.title: Vasco da Gama's First Voyage Begins
07-08.description: On July 8, 1497, Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama departed on his first voyage, becoming the first European to reach India by sea.

07-08.title: Vermont Prohibits Slavery
07-08.description: On July 8, 1777, the independent Republic of Vermont introduced a new constitution that prohibited slavery.

07-08.title: First Cowpox Vaccination in U.S.
07-08.description: On July 8, 1800, Dr. Benjamin Waterhouse gave the first cowpox vaccination in the United States to his son to prevent smallpox.

07-08.title: Commodore Perry Arrives in Japan
07-08.description: On July 8, 1853, Commodore Matthew C. Perry sailed his frigate into Tokyo Bay, beginning the process of opening Japan to Western influence and trade.

07-08.title: Russian Orthodox Church Celebrates 500th Anniversary
07-08.description: On July 8, 1948, the 500th anniversary of the autocephaly of the Russian Orthodox Church was celebrated in Moscow.

07-08.title: South Africa's Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Act
07-08.description: On July 8, 1949, South Africa's Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Act commenced, prohibiting marriage between White people and people of other races.

07-09.title: Tamerlane Destroys Baghdad
07-09.description: On July 9, 1401, Turko-Mongol ruler Tamerlane (Timur) destroyed Baghdad, killing 20,000 people.

07-09.title: Second Battle of Svensksund
07-09.description: On July 9, 1790, Swedish naval forces won a victory over the Russian Baltic fleet during the Second Battle of Svensksund, ending the Russo-Swedish War.

07-09.title: 14th Amendment Ratified
07-09.description: On July 9, 1868, Louisiana and South Carolina ratified the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution, securing its adoption.

07-09.title: First Successful Open-Heart Surgery
07-09.description: On July 9, 1893, surgeon Daniel Hale Williams performed the first successful open-heart surgery by repairing the pericardium of a knife wound patient.

07-09.title: HMS Vanguard Explodes
07-09.description: On July 9, 1917, the British battleship HMS Vanguard exploded at Scapa Flow due to a faulty cordite explosion, killing 804 crew members.

07-09.title: Kissinger's Secret Visit to China
07-09.description: On July 9, 1971, National Security Advisor Henry Kissinger secretly visited the People's Republic of China to negotiate a detente.

07-09.title: African Union Established
07-09.description: On July 9, 2002, the African Union was established in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, with Thabo Mbeki as its first chairman.

07-09.title: Iraq Declares Victory Over ISIS in Mosul
07-09.description: On July 9, 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi proclaimed victory over Islamic State forces in Mosul.

07-10.title: Battle of Britain Begins
07-10.description: On July 10, 1940, the Battle of Britain began as Nazi forces attacked shipping convoys in the English Channel.

07-10.title: Sinking of the Rainbow Warrior
07-10.description: On July 10, 1985, French foreign intelligence agents blew up the Greenpeace flagship Rainbow Warrior in Auckland harbor, New Zealand.

07-10.title: Boris Yeltsin Sworn in as Russian President
07-10.description: On July 10, 1991, Boris Yeltsin was sworn in as the first elected President of the Russian Federation.

07-10.title: American Episcopal Church Approves Gay Marriage Rite
07-10.description: On July 10, 2012, the American Episcopal Church became the first major Christian denomination in the U.S. to approve a rite for blessing gay marriages.

07-11.title: Zheng He's First Expedition
07-11.description: On July 11, 1405, Chinese fleet commander Zheng He set sail to the Spice Islands on his first major expedition with over 200 vessels.

07-11.title: King Henry VIII Excommunicated
07-11.description: On July 11, 1533, Pope Clement VII excommunicated England's King Henry VIII.

07-11.title: John Keats Writes Several Poems
07-11.description: On July 11, 1818, English poet John Keats wrote 'In the Cottage Where Burns is Born,' 'Lines Written in the Highlands,' and 'Gadfly'.

07-11.title: First Woman Graduate in New Zealand
07-11.description: On July 11, 1877, Kate Edger became New Zealand’s first woman graduate and the first woman in the British Empire to earn a Bachelor of Arts.

07-11.title: Andrée's North Pole Balloon Expedition
07-11.description: On July 11, 1897, Salomon August Andrée and his crew left Spitsbergen, Norway, by balloon, in an ill-fated attempt to reach the North Pole.

07-11.title: Franklin Roosevelt Announces Fourth-Term Run
07-11.description: On July 11, 1944, Franklin Roosevelt announced he would run for a fourth term as President of the United States.

07-11.title: Srebrenica Massacre
07-11.description: On July 11, 1995, more than 8,000 Bosnian Muslim men and boys were massacred by Bosnian Serbs after they overran the UN 'safe haven' of Srebrenica.

07-12.title: Minamoto Yoritomo Becomes First Ruling Shogun of Japan
07-12.description: On July 12, 1192, Minamoto Yoritomo became Seii Taishōgun, the first ruling shogun in the history of Japan and its de facto ruler.

07-12.title: King Charles II Ratifies Habeas Corpus Act
07-12.description: On July 12, 1679, Britain's King Charles II ratified the Habeas Corpus Act, allowing prisoners the right to a court review of their imprisonment.

07-12.title: French Revolution: Civil Constitution of the Clergy Adopted
07-12.description: On July 12, 1790, the Civil Constitution of the Clergy was adopted, putting the Catholic Church in France under the control of the state.

07-12.title: Alexander Hamilton Dies After Duel
07-12.description: On July 12, 1804, former United States Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton died after being shot in a pistol duel by Vice President Aaron Burr.

07-12.title: New Zealand Wars: British Forces Invade Waikato
07-12.description: On July 12, 1863, British forces invaded the Waikato region in New Zealand, home of the Māori King Movement, beginning a new phase of the New Zealand Wars.

07-12.title: Ulstermen Resolve to Resist Irish Home Rule
07-12.description: On July 12, 1913, 150,000 Ulstermen gathered and resolved to resist Irish Home Rule by force of arms.

07-12.title: Battle of Prokhorovka
07-12.description: On July 12, 1943, Russia defeated German forces in the Battle of Prokhorovka, one of the largest tank battles in history.

07-12.title: U.S. Surgeon General Links Smoking to Lung Cancer
07-12.description: On July 12, 1957, US Surgeon General Leroy Burney publicly linked smoking to lung cancer.

07-13.title: Captain Cook's Second Voyage Begins
07-13.description: On July 13, 1772, Captain James Cook began his second voyage to the South Seas aboard HMS Resolution to search for Terra Australis (Southern Continent).

07-13.title: Source of Mississippi River Discovered
07-13.description: On July 13, 1832, the source of the Mississippi River was discovered by American geographer Henry Schoolcraft.

07-13.title: Screw Propeller Design Patented
07-13.description: On July 13, 1835, Swedish-American inventor John Ericsson filed for a patent for his screw propeller design.

07-13.title: Ems Telegram Sent
07-13.description: On July 13, 1870, King Wilhelm I of Prussia sent the 'Ems Telegram' to Otto von Bismarck, who published an edited version to provoke the Franco-German War.

07-13.title: Hare Krishna Movement Founded
07-13.description: On July 13, 1966, A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada founded the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (Hare Krishna movement) in New York City.

07-13.title: Donald Trump Assassination Attempt
07-13.description: On July 13, 2024, former US President Donald Trump survived an assassination attempt at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.

07-14.title: Storming of the Bastille
07-14.description: On July 14, 1789, the French Revolution began with the storming of the Bastille prison in Paris, an event now celebrated as France's National Day.

07-14.title: U.S. Sedition Act Passed
07-14.description: On July 14, 1798, the U.S. Sedition Act was passed, prohibiting 'any false, scandalous, and malicious writing' about the government.

07-14.title: First Public Demonstration of Refrigerated Ice
07-14.description: On July 14, 1850, the first public demonstration of ice made via refrigeration was conducted by Florida physician John Gorrie.

07-14.title: Nazi Germany Becomes a One-Party State
07-14.description: On July 14, 1933, all non-Nazi political parties were banned in Germany.

07-14.title: Open Source OS 386BSD Released
07-14.description: On July 14, 1992, 386BSD was released by Lynne and William Jolitz, starting the open source operating system revolution. Linus Torvalds released Linux soon after.

07-15.title: Jerusalem Captured During First Crusade
07-15.description: On July 15, 1099, the city of Jerusalem was captured and plundered by Christian forces during the First Crusade.

07-15.title: Peasants' Revolt Leader Executed
07-15.description: On July 15, 1381, John Ball, a leader in the Peasants' Revolt, was hanged, drawn and quartered in the presence of Richard II of England.

07-15.title: Battle of Grunwald
07-15.description: On July 15, 1410, Polish and Lithuanian forces defeated the Teutonic Knights in the Battle of Grunwald, one of Medieval Europe's largest battles.

07-15.title: Rosetta Stone Found
07-15.description: On July 15, 1799, the Rosetta Stone was found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard.

07-15.title: Nobel Laureates Sign Anti-Nuclear Declaration
07-15.description: On July 15, 1955, eighteen Nobel laureates signed the Mainau Declaration against nuclear weapons, later co-signed by 34 more.

07-16.title: Islamic Era Begins
07-16.description: On July 16, 622, the Islamic Era began as Muhammad and his followers started their migration (Hijra) from Mecca to Medina.

07-16.title: Great Schism Begins
07-16.description: On July 16, 1054, the Great Schism between the Western and Eastern churches began when mutual excommunications were issued in Rome and Constantinople.

07-16.title: Martin Luther Debates Johann Eck
07-16.description: On July 16, 1519, a public debate between Martin Luther and theologian Johann Eck took place, during which Luther denied the divine right of the Pope.

07-16.title: First Independent Government in Spanish America
07-16.description: On July 16, 1809, La Paz, Bolivia, declared its independence from the Spanish Crown, forming the first independent government in Spanish America.

07-16.title: Hitler Orders Preparations for Invasion of Britain
07-16.description: On July 16, 1940, Adolf Hitler ordered preparations for Operation Sealion, the planned invasion of Britain.

07-16.title: First Atomic Bomb Test
07-16.description: On July 16, 1945, the first test detonation of an atomic bomb occurred at Trinity Site, New Mexico, as part of the U.S. Manhattan Project.

07-17.title: Earliest Recorded Instance of Christianity in North Africa
07-17.description: On July 17, 180, six residents of Carthage, North Africa, were executed for being Christian, the earliest recorded instance of Christianity in the region.

07-17.title: Fourth Crusade: Siege of Constantinople Begins
07-17.description: On July 17, 1203, the Siege of Constantinople began as Roman Catholic Crusaders attacked the city.

07-17.title: Catherine the Great Becomes Tsarina of Russia
07-17.description: On July 17, 1762, Empress Catherine II became Tsarina of Russia after the death of Tsar Peter III.

07-17.title: Execution of the Romanov Family
07-17.description: On July 17, 1918, the Romanov royal family and several of their retainers were executed by a Bolshevik firing squad in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

07-17.title: Spanish Civil War Begins
07-17.description: On July 17, 1936, Spanish generals Francisco Franco and Emilio Mola led a right-wing uprising, starting the Spanish Civil War.

07-17.title: Potsdam Conference Begins
07-17.description: On July 17, 1945, leaders Harry Truman, Joseph Stalin, and Winston Churchill held their first post-World War II meeting at the Potsdam Conference.

07-17.title: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Shot Down
07-17.description: On July 17, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down over Eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 people on board.

07-18.title: Great Fire of Rome
07-18.description: On July 18, 64, the Great Fire of Rome began under the Emperor Nero.

07-18.title: Construction of Florence Cathedral's Bell Tower Begins
07-18.description: On July 18, 1334, the first foundation stone was laid for the new campanile (bell tower) of the Florence Cathedral, designed by Giotto di Bondone.

07-18.title: Adolf Hitler Publishes 'Mein Kampf'
07-18.description: On July 18, 1925, Adolf Hitler published his autobiographical manifesto, 'Mein Kampf'.

07-18.title: Francisco Franco Leads Uprising in Spanish Morocco
07-18.description: On July 18, 1936, General Francisco Franco issued a manifesto and led an uprising in the Spanish army stationed in Morocco, a key event in the start of the Spanish Civil War.

07-18.title: Kim Jong-un Appointed Supreme Leader of North Korea
07-18.description: On July 18, 2012, Kim Jong-un was officially appointed Supreme Leader of North Korea and given the rank of Marshal.

07-18.title: Detroit Files for Bankruptcy
07-18.description: On July 18, 2013, Detroit, Michigan, filed for bankruptcy, becoming the largest U.S. municipal bankruptcy at $18.5 billion.

07-18.title: 2023 Canadian Wildfire Season Becomes Most Destructive
07-18.description: On July 18, 2023, the wildfire season in British Columbia became the most destructive on record, surpassing the 2018 record.

07-19.title: Kepler Develops Theory of the Universe
07-19.description: On July 19, 1595, astronomer Johannes Kepler had an epiphany and developed his theory of the geometrical basis of the universe.

07-19.title: Steamship SS Great Britain Launched
07-19.description: On July 19, 1843, the steamship SS Great Britain was launched. Designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, it was the first ocean-going craft with an iron hull and screw propeller.

07-19.title: First U.S. Women's Rights Convention
07-19.description: On July 19, 1848, the first U.S. women's rights convention was held in Seneca Falls, NY, organized by Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott.

07-19.title: Sioux Chief Sitting Bull Surrenders
07-19.description: On July 19, 1881, Sioux Chief Sitting Bull surrendered to U.S. federal troops at Fort Buford in the Territory of Montana.

07-19.title: Winston Churchill Launches 'V for Victory' Campaign
07-19.description: On July 19, 1941, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill launched his 'V for Victory' campaign.

07-20.title: First European Crossing of North America Completed
07-20.description: On July 20, 1793, Scottish explorer Alexander Mackenzie completed the first European east-to-west crossing of America north of Mexico.

07-20.title: First Woman Presides Over U.S. House of Representatives
07-20.description: On July 20, 1921, Congresswoman Alice Mary Robertson became the first woman to preside over the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives.

07-20.title: Apollo 11 Lands on the Moon
07-20.description: On July 20, 1969, NASA's Apollo 11 lunar module landed on the Moon. Hours later, Neil Armstrong became the first person to walk on its surface.

07-20.title: Viking 1 Lands on Mars
07-20.description: On July 20, 1976, Viking 1 landed on Mars at Chryse Planitia, the first successful landing on the planet.

07-20.title: China Announces Ban on 'Foreign Garbage'
07-20.description: On July 20, 2017, China announced a plan to ban the import of 24 categories of plastic and recyclable waste starting in 2018.

07-21.title: Temple of Artemis Burned Down
07-21.description: On July 21, 356 BC, Herostratus set fire to the Temple of Artemis in Ephesus, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.

07-21.title: Crete Earthquake and Tsunami
07-21.description: On July 21, 365, an earthquake on Crete, followed by a tsunami, devastated the Eastern Mediterranean and allegedly destroyed Alexandria.

07-21.title: First Battle of Bull Run
07-21.description: On July 21, 1861, the First Battle of Bull Run, the first major battle of the U.S. Civil War, was fought and ended in a Confederate victory.

07-21.title: Trans-Siberian Railway Completed
07-21.description: On July 21, 1904, after 13 years, the 4,607-mile Trans-Siberian Railway was completed.

07-21.title: Scopes 'Monkey Trial' Verdict
07-21.description: On July 21, 1925, John T. Scopes was found guilty of teaching evolution in the 'Scopes monkey trial' in Dayton, Tennessee, and fined $100.

07-21.title: Geneva Accords Signed
07-21.description: On July 21, 1954, the Geneva Accords for Indochina were signed, dividing the region into North Vietnam, South Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos.

07-21.title: Aswan High Dam Opens
07-21.description: On July 21, 1970, the Aswan High Dam opened in Egypt, enabling human control of the flooding of the Nile.

07-21.title: HistoryOrb.com Becomes OnThisDay.com
07-21.description: On July 21, 2015, the website HistoryOrb.com changed its domain name and brand to OnThisDay.com.

07-21.title: Joe Biden Withdraws from Presidential Race
07-21.description: On July 21, 2024, US President Joe Biden abandoned his campaign for re-election and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris.

07-22.title: First Defender of the Holy Sepulchre Elected
07-22.description: On July 22, 1099, Godfrey of Bouillon was elected the first Defender of the Holy Sepulchre of the Kingdom of Jerusalem during the First Crusade.

07-22.title: Siege of Belgrade Ends
07-22.description: On July 22, 1456, a Hungarian army under John Hunyadi defeated Ottoman forces, ending the Siege of Belgrade and halting Ottoman expansion for 70 years.

07-22.title: First Congress of Vienna
07-22.description: On July 22, 1515, the First Congress of Vienna settled issues between Poland and the Holy Roman Empire, demonstrating the Habsburgs' growing influence.

07-22.title: Mass Deportation from Warsaw Ghetto to Treblinka
07-22.description: On July 22, 1942, the mass deportation of Jews from the Warsaw Ghetto to the Treblinka extermination camp began.

07-22.title: Sarawak Achieves Independence
07-22.description: On July 22, 1963, Sarawak achieved independence from British colonial rule before joining the Federation of Malaysia.

07-22.title: Twin Terror Attacks in Norway
07-22.description: On July 22, 2011, Norway was the victim of twin terror attacks: a bomb blast in Oslo and a massacre at a youth camp on the island of Utøya.

07-23.title: France Agrees to Supply U.S. in Revolutionary War
07-23.description: On July 23, 1777, King Louis XVI of France and his Foreign Minister clandestinely agreed to supply the United States with munitions.

07-23.title: First U.S. Typewriter Patented
07-23.description: On July 23, 1829, William Austin Burt patented America's first typewriter, the typographer.

07-23.title: Union Act Unites Upper and Lower Canada
07-23.description: On July 23, 1840, the Union Act was passed by the British Parliament, uniting Upper and Lower Canada into the Province of Canada.

07-23.title: Bretton Woods Conference Ends
07-23.description: On July 23, 1944, the Bretton Woods Conference ended, establishing the International Monetary Fund and the precursor to the World Bank.

07-23.title: Comet Hale-Bopp Discovered
07-23.description: On July 23, 1995, Comet Hale-Bopp was discovered and became visible to the naked eye nearly a year later.

07-24.title: Jacques Cartier Claims Gaspé Peninsula for France
07-24.description: On July 24, 1534, French explorer Jacques Cartier claimed the lands around Gaspé, Quebec for France by erecting a 30-foot cross.

07-24.title: Mary, Queen of Scots, Forced to Abdicate
07-24.description: On July 24, 1567, Mary, Queen of Scots, was forced to abdicate; her 1-year-old son became King James VI of Scotland.

07-24.title: First Wagon Train Crosses Rocky Mountains via South Pass
07-24.description: On July 24, 1832, Benjamin Bonneville led the first wagon train across the Rocky Mountains through Wyoming's South Pass.

07-24.title: Hiram Bingham Rediscovers Machu Picchu
07-24.description: On July 24, 1911, American explorer Hiram Bingham rediscovered Machu Picchu, the Lost City of the Incas.

07-24.title: Operation Gomorrah: Bombing of Hamburg Begins
07-24.description: On July 24, 1943, the RAF began bombing Hamburg in Operation Gomorrah, creating a firestorm and killing 42,600 people.

07-24.title: Reports Confirm Unprecedented Global Warming Speed
07-24.description: On July 24, 2019, major reports confirmed that global warming is the fastest in 2,000 years and that the scientific consensus on human cause is at 99%.

07-25.title: Constantine I Proclaimed Roman Emperor
07-25.description: On July 25, 306, Constantine I was proclaimed Roman Emperor by his troops.

07-25.title: George Stephenson Introduces First Steam Locomotive
07-25.description: On July 25, 1814, English engineer George Stephenson introduced his first steam locomotive, designed for hauling coal.

07-25.title: Benito Mussolini Overthrown
07-25.description: On July 25, 1943, Benito Mussolini was dismissed as Italian Prime Minister and arrested on the authority of King Victor Emmanuel III.

07-25.title: Operation Spring: A Bloody Day for Canadian Forces
07-25.description: On July 25, 1944, Operation Spring became one of Canada's bloodiest days of World War II, with 1,444 casualties, including 441 killed.

07-25.title: First Human Stem Cells Cultured in Lab
07-25.description: On July 25, 1997, scientists announced the first human stem cells had been cultured in a laboratory using tissue from aborted human embryos.

07-26.title: Battle of Siffin
07-26.description: On July 26, 657, the Battle of Siffin occurred during the first Muslim civil war between Ali ibn Abi Talib and Muawiyah I.

07-26.title: Francisco Pizarro Receives Royal Charter
07-26.description: On July 26, 1529, Francisco Pizarro received a royal charter for the conquest of Peru.

07-26.title: Pizarro Orders Death of Inca Emperor Atahualpa
07-26.description: On July 26, 1533, Francisco Pizarro ordered the death of the last Sapa Inca Emperor, Atahualpa.

07-26.title: World's First Public Railway Opens
07-26.description: On July 26, 1803, the Surrey Iron Railway, arguably the world's first public railway, opened in south London.

07-26.title: Forerunner to the FBI Established
07-26.description: On July 26, 1908, the U.S. Attorney General ordered the staffing of the Office of the Chief Examiner, later renamed the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

07-26.title: Potsdam Declaration Demands Japan's Surrender
07-26.description: On July 26, 1945, the U.S., Britain, and China demanded the unconditional surrender of Japan in the Declaration of Potsdam.

07-26.title: Fidel Castro's Failed Attack on Moncada Barracks
07-26.description: On July 26, 1953, Fidel Castro led a failed attack on the Moncada Barracks, an event considered the start of the Cuban Revolution.

07-27.title: Walter Raleigh Brings Tobacco to England
07-27.description: On July 27, 1586, Walter Raleigh brought the first tobacco to England from Virginia.

07-27.title: Battle of Killiecrankie
07-27.description: On July 27, 1689, at the Battle of Killiecrankie, Jacobite Scottish Highlanders defeated royalist forces.

07-27.title: U.S. Department of Foreign Affairs Established
07-27.description: On July 27, 1789, the U.S. Congress established the Department of Foreign Affairs, now known as the State Department.

07-27.title: First Transatlantic Telegraph Cable Lands
07-27.description: On July 27, 1866, the first successful transatlantic telegraph cable came ashore at Heart's Content, Newfoundland.

07-27.title: Insulin Isolated
07-27.description: On July 27, 1921, Frederick Banting and Charles Best isolated insulin at the University of Toronto.

07-28.title: Execution of Maximilien Robespierre
07-28.description: On July 28, 1794, French Revolutionary figure Maximilien Robespierre and 22 other leaders of 'the Terror' were guillotined in Paris.

07-28.title: World War I Begins
07-28.description: On July 28, 1914, Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia, marking the official start of World War I.

07-28.title: Silent Parade Protests Lynching
07-28.description: On July 28, 1917, in a 'Silent Parade' organized by James Weldon Johnson, 10,000 African Americans marched on Fifth Avenue in NYC to protest against lynching.

07-28.title: Hamburg Firestorm
07-28.description: On July 28, 1943, RAF bombing during Operation Gomorrah caused a firestorm in Hamburg that killed 42,600 German civilians.

07-28.title: Tangshan Earthquake
07-28.description: On July 28, 1976, the Tangshan Earthquake, 7.6 in magnitude, killed over 240,000 people in northern China, the deadliest earthquake of the 20th century.

07-28.title: Provisional IRA Ends Armed Campaign
07-28.description: On July 28, 2005, the Provisional Irish Republican Army called an end to its 30-year-long armed campaign in Northern Ireland.

07-29.title: Defeat of the Spanish Armada
07-29.description: On July 29, 1588, the Spanish Armada was sighted off England. A series of skirmishes followed, forcing the invading fleet into a long and costly retreat.

07-29.title: Champlain's Encounter with the Iroquois
07-29.description: On July 29, 1609, Samuel de Champlain shot and killed two Iroquois chiefs at Ticonderoga, New York, setting the stage for French-Iroquois conflicts.

07-29.title: Tipperary Revolt During Irish Potato Famine
07-29.description: On July 29, 1848, during the Irish Potato Famine, the Tipperary Revolt, an unsuccessful nationalist uprising against British rule, was put down by police.

07-29.title: Taft-Katsura Agreement
07-29.description: On July 29, 1905, U.S. Secretary of War William Howard Taft made a secret agreement with Japanese Prime Minister Katsura regarding Korea and the Philippines.

07-29.title: Adolf Hitler Becomes Leader of Nazi Party
07-29.description: On July 29, 1921, Adolf Hitler became leader of the National Socialist German Workers' Party.

07-30.title: Battle of Alexandria
07-30.description: On July 30, 30 BC, Mark Antony achieved a minor victory over Octavian at the Battle of Alexandria, but his army subsequently deserted.

07-30.title: Frederick I Barbarossa Crowned King of Burgundy
07-30.description: On July 30, 1178, Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa was crowned King of Burgundy.

07-30.title: First Defenestration of Prague
07-30.description: On July 30, 1419, anti-Catholic Hussites stormed Prague Town Hall and threw the judge, mayor, and several council members out the windows.

07-30.title: First Elected American Governing Body Forms
07-30.description: On July 30, 1619, the House of Burgesses formed in Virginia, the first elected American governing body.

07-30.title: Shoshone Tribe Signs Treaty of Box Elder
07-30.description: On July 30, 1863, Chief Pocatello of the Shoshone tribe signed the Treaty of Box Elder, promising to stop harassing emigrant trails.

07-30.title: World's First Oil Tanker Departs
07-30.description: On July 30, 1869, the world's first oil tanker, 'The Charles,' departed the United States for Europe, carrying 7,000 barrels of oil.

07-30.title: First Penguin Books Published
07-30.description: On July 30, 1935, the first Penguin Books were published, starting the paperback revolution.

07-30.title: Soviet Politburo Issues NKVD Order No. 00447
07-30.description: On July 30, 1937, the Soviet Politburo issued NKVD Order No. 00447 during the Great Purge, leading to the arrest of 269,100 people and execution of 76,000.

07-31.title: Pilgrim Fathers Depart for England
07-31.description: On July 31, 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers departed Leiden, Netherlands, for England on their way to America.

07-31.title: Battle of Passchendaele Begins
07-31.description: On July 31, 1917, the Battle of Passchendaele (Third Battle of Ypres) began, lasting until November and causing approximately 500,000 casualties.

07-31.title: Israel Welcomes One-Millionth Immigrant
07-31.description: On July 31, 1961, Israel welcomed its one-millionth immigrant.

07-31.title: Black Tot Day: Royal Navy Ends Rum Ration
07-31.description: On July 31, 1970, on 'Black Tot Day,' the last officially sanctioned rum ration in the Royal Navy was issued, ending a tradition that started in 1740.

07-31.title: Operation Banner Ends in Northern Ireland
07-31.description: On July 31, 2007, Operation Banner, the presence of the British Army in Northern Ireland and its longest-running operation, came to an end.

08-01.title: Justinian I Becomes Sole Byzantine Ruler
08-01.description: On August 1, 527, Justinian I became the sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire after the death of his uncle Justin I.

08-01.title: Domesday Book Survey Presented
08-01.description: On August 1, 1086, the results of the Domesday survey were presented to William the Conqueror in Salisbury.

08-01.title: Oxygen Discovered
08-01.description: On August 1, 1774, English chemist Joseph Priestley discovered oxygen by isolating it in its gaseous state.

08-01.title: Slavery Abolished Across British Empire
08-01.description: On August 1, 1834, the Slavery Abolition Act 1833 came into effect, abolishing slavery across the British Empire.

08-01.title: USS Nautilus Begins First Transit of North Pole
08-01.description: On August 1, 1958, the nuclear-powered submarine USS Nautilus began the first-ever underwater transit of the North Pole.

08-01.title: Donald Trump Indicted for Efforts to Overturn 2020 Election
08-01.description: On August 1, 2023, former US President Donald Trump was indicted by special counsel Jack Smith on charges of conspiring to defraud the country and obstruct the peaceful transfer of power.
