08-02.title: Battle of Chaeronea
08-02.description: On August 2, 338 BC, the Macedonian army led by Philip II defeated the combined forces of Athens and Thebes, securing Macedonian hegemony over Greece.

08-02.title: Battle of Cannae
08-02.description: On August 2, 216 BC, during the Second Punic War, Hannibal's Carthaginian army defeated a numerically superior Roman army at the Battle of Cannae.

08-02.title: Formal Signing of U.S. Declaration of Independence
08-02.description: On August 2, 1776, the formal signing of the U.S. Declaration of Independence by 56 delegates took place.

08-02.title: First U.S. Census Conducted
08-02.description: On August 2, 1790, the first U.S. census was conducted; the population was 3,929,214, including 697,624 slaves.

08-02.title: Battle of Bad Axe Ends Black Hawk War
08-02.description: On August 2, 1832, the Battle of Bad Axe in Wisconsin ended with the defeat of Sauk and Fox Native Americans, concluding the Black Hawk War.

08-02.title: Government of India Transferred to British Crown
08-02.description: On August 2, 1858, the Government of India was transferred from the East India Company to the British Crown.

08-02.title: Apple Reaches $1 Trillion Market Value
08-02.description: On August 2, 2018, Apple became the first American publicly listed company to reach $1 trillion in value.

08-02.title: Nancy Pelosi Visits Taiwan
08-02.description: On August 2, 2022, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi became the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit Taiwan in 25 years, prompting condemnation from China.

08-03.title: Christopher Columbus's First Voyage
08-03.description: On August 3, 1492, Christopher Columbus set sail on his first voyage with three ships—the Santa María, Pinta, and Niña—from Palos de la Frontera, Spain.

08-03.title: First Variable Star Discovered
08-03.description: On August 3, 1596, German astronomer David Fabricius discovered the light variation of Mira, the first identified variable star.

08-03.title: Germany Invades Belgium, Declares War on France
08-03.description: On August 3, 1914, Germany invaded Belgium and declared war on France, marking a major escalation at the beginning of World War I.

08-03.title: Adolf Hitler Becomes 'Führer' of Germany
08-03.description: On August 3, 1934, Adolf Hitler merged the offices of German Chancellor and President, declaring himself 'Führer' (leader).

08-03.title: U.S. Senate Ratifies Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty
08-03.description: On August 3, 1972, the U.S. Senate ratified the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty with the Soviet Union.

08-04.title: First Printing of the Zohar
08-04.description: On August 4, 1558, the first printing of the Zohar in Spain popularized the Jewish study of Kabbalah.

08-04.title: Russian Antarctic Expedition Returns
08-04.description: On August 4, 1821, the Russian Antarctic expedition led by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen returned to Kronstadt after being the first to circumnavigate Antarctica.

08-04.title: U.S. Declares Neutrality in WWI
08-04.description: On August 4, 1914, US President Woodrow Wilson issued his 'Proclamation of Neutrality' to keep the United States out of the war in Europe.

08-04.title: First Deportation Train from Mechelen to Auschwitz
08-04.description: On August 4, 1942, the first train carrying Jews departed from Mechelen, Belgium, for Auschwitz.

08-04.title: Anne Frank Arrested
08-04.description: On August 4, 1944, Anne Frank and her family were arrested in Amsterdam by German Security Police following a tip-off from an informant.

08-04.title: Rwandan Peace Treaty Signed
08-04.description: On August 4, 1993, Rwandan Hutus and Tutsis signed a peace treaty in Arusha, Tanzania, aimed at ending the Rwandan Civil War.

08-05.title: Battle of Tettenhall
08-05.description: On August 5, 910, the last major Viking army to raid England was defeated at the Battle of Tettenhall by the allied forces of Mercia and Wessex.

08-05.title: William Wallace Captured
08-05.description: On August 5, 1305, Scottish resistance leader William Wallace was captured by the English near Glasgow and transported to London for trial and execution.

08-05.title: First English Colony in North America Established
08-05.description: On August 5, 1583, Humphrey Gilbert claimed Newfoundland for the English crown, establishing the first English colony in North America.

08-05.title: Battle of Petrovaradin
08-05.description: On August 5, 1716, Habsburg forces under Eugene of Savoy defeated the Ottomans in a decisive victory at the Battle of Petrovaradin.

08-05.title: Battle of Mobile Bay
08-05.description: On August 5, 1864, the Battle of Mobile Bay was won by the Union Navy, led by Rear Admiral David Farragut with his famous cry, 'Damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead!'

08-06.title: John Cabot Returns from North America
08-06.description: On August 6, 1497, Italian explorer John Cabot returned to Bristol from North America (Newfoundland), the first European to do so since the Vikings.

08-06.title: Dutch Sell Brazil to Portugal
08-06.description: On August 6, 1661, the Treaty of The Hague was signed, whereby the Dutch Republic sold New Holland (Brazil) to Portugal for 63 tons of gold.

08-06.title: First Execution by Electric Chair
08-06.description: On August 6, 1890, murderer William Kemmler became the first person executed by electric chair at Auburn Prison in New York.

08-06.title: Atomic Bombing of Hiroshima
08-06.description: On August 6, 1945, an atomic bomb was dropped on the Japanese city of Hiroshima by the U.S. B-29 Superfortress 'Enola Gay'.

08-06.title: Voting Rights Act Signed
08-06.description: On August 6, 1965, US President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, prohibiting voting discrimination against minorities.

08-06.title: World Wide Web Debuts as Public Service
08-06.description: On August 6, 1991, Tim Berners-Lee released files describing his idea for the World Wide Web and debuted it as a publicly available service on the internet.

08-07.title: Cao Qin's Coup Attempt in Ming China
08-07.description: On August 7, 1461, Ming Dynasty Chinese military general Cao Qin staged a coup against the Tianshun Emperor.

08-07.title: Battle of Gangut
08-07.description: On August 7, 1714, at the Battle of Gangut, the Russian Navy won its first major victory during the Great Northern War against Sweden.

08-07.title: George Washington Creates Badge of Military Merit
08-07.description: On August 7, 1782, George Washington created the Badge of Military Merit (now the Purple Heart), the first time military awards were presented to common soldiers.

08-07.title: Simele Massacre in Iraq
08-07.description: On August 7, 1933, Iraqi government forces slaughtered over 3,000 Assyrians in the village of Simele, an event commemorated as Assyrian Martyrs Day.

08-07.title: First Sony Transistor Radios Sold
08-07.description: On August 7, 1955, Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering, the precursor to Sony, began selling its first transistor radios in Japan.

08-07.title: Operation Desert Shield Begins
08-07.description: On August 7, 1990, the U.S. deployed troops to Saudi Arabia, beginning Operation Desert Shield in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

08-08.title: Krishnadeva Raya Crowned Emperor
08-08.description: On August 8, 1509, Emperor Krishnadeva Raya was crowned, beginning the rejuvenation of the Vijayanagara Empire in southern India.

08-08.title: Galileo Presents His Telescope
08-08.description: On August 8, 1609, Galileo Galilei presented his first telescope to the Venetian Senate in Venice.

08-08.title: U.S. Congress Chooses Dollar as Monetary Unit
08-08.description: On August 8, 1786, the U.S. Congress unanimously chose the dollar as the monetary unit for the United States.

08-08.title: Soviet Union Declares War on Japan
08-08.description: On August 8, 1945, the Soviet Union declared war on Japan during World War II and invaded Manchuria the next day.

08-08.title: Richard Nixon Announces Resignation
08-08.description: On August 8, 1974, US President Richard Nixon announced he would resign at 12 p.m. the next day.

08-08.title: Iran-Iraq War Ceasefire
08-08.description: On August 8, 1988, a ceasefire between Iran and Iraq took effect after eight years of war.

08-09.title: Battle of Pharsalus
08-09.description: On August 9, 48 BC, Julius Caesar decisively defeated Pompey the Great at the Battle of Pharsalus, forcing Pompey to flee to Egypt.

08-09.title: Battle of Adrianople
08-09.description: On August 9, 378, a Gothic rebel army defeated Roman forces at the Battle of Adrianople, and Emperor Valens was killed.

08-09.title: First American Ship Circumnavigates the Globe
08-09.description: On August 9, 1790, Robert Gray's 'Columbia Rediviva' returned to Boston after a 3-year journey, becoming the first American ship to circumnavigate the globe.

08-09.title: Rudolf Diesel Patents Diesel Engine
08-09.description: On August 9, 1898, Rudolf Diesel of Germany obtained a patent for his internal combustion engine, later known as the diesel engine.

08-09.title: Mahatma Gandhi Arrested After 'Quit India' Motion
08-09.description: On August 9, 1942, Mahatma Gandhi and 50 others were arrested in Bombay after the passing of a 'Quit India' motion by the All India Congress Committee.

08-09.title: Atomic Bombing of Nagasaki
08-09.description: On August 9, 1945, the U.S. dropped the second atomic bomb, 'Fat Man,' on Nagasaki, Japan.

08-09.title: Singapore Gains Independence
08-09.description: On August 9, 1965, Singapore separated from the Federation of Malaysia and gained its independence.

08-09.title: Richard Nixon Resigns
08-09.description: On August 9, 1974, Richard Nixon resigned as President of the United States, and Vice President Gerald Ford was sworn in as the 38th U.S. President.

08-09.title: Disputed Belarusian Presidential Election
08-09.description: On August 9, 2020, a disputed presidential election in Belarus, which saw longtime dictator Alexander Lukashenko claim victory, sparked widespread protests and international condemnation.

08-10.title: Fall of Nineveh
08-10.description: On approximately August 10, 612 BC, the fall of Nineveh to Babylonians and Medes led to the destruction of the Neo-Assyrian Empire.

08-10.title: Traditional Date of the 'Night of Power'
08-10.description: On August 10, 610, is the traditional date of Laylat al-Qadr (the Night of Power), when Muslims believe the Quran was first revealed to the prophet Muhammad.

08-10.title: John Cabot Reports on Voyage to 'Asia'
08-10.description: On August 10, 1497, explorer John Cabot told King Henry VII of his trip to 'Asia' (North America).

08-10.title: Royal Observatory in Greenwich Founded
08-10.description: On August 10, 1675, King Charles II and John Flamsteed laid the foundation stone of the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, London.

08-10.title: Smithsonian Institution Established
08-10.description: On August 10, 1846, the U.S. Congress passed an act to establish the Smithsonian Institution.

08-11.title: Traditional Start of Mesoamerican Long Count Calendar
08-11.description: On August 11, 3114 BC, this is traditionally considered the start date of the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar, used notably by the Maya.

08-11.title: Allies Refuse Japan's Conditional Surrender
08-11.description: On August 11, 1945, the Allies refused Japan's offer to surrender on the condition that Emperor Hirohito retain his status.

08-11.title: First Indochina War Peace Treaty
08-11.description: On August 11, 1954, a formal peace treaty ended over seven years of fighting in Indochina between the French and the Communist Viet Minh.

08-11.title: Al-Qaeda Formed
08-11.description: On August 11, 1988, Al-Qaeda was formed at a meeting between Osama Bin Laden, Ayman al-Zawahiri, and others in Peshawar, Pakistan.

08-11.title: NATO Takes Command of Peacekeeping in Afghanistan
08-11.description: On August 11, 2003, NATO took over command of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, its first major operation outside Europe.

08-12.title: Battle of Didgori
08-12.description: On August 12, 1121, the Georgian army under King David the Builder won a decisive victory over the Seljuk army at the Battle of Didgori.

08-12.title: Ottoman Troops Conquer Otranto
08-12.description: On August 12, 1480, Ottoman troops conquered Otranto in southern Italy, killing 12,000 and enslaving 5,000.

08-12.title: Isaac Singer Patents Sewing Machine
08-12.description: On August 12, 1851, American inventor Isaac Singer patented his famous sewing machine.

08-12.title: First Ford Model T Built
08-12.description: On August 12, 1908, the Ford Motor Company built its first Model T car.

08-12.title: IBM PC Unveiled
08-12.description: On August 12, 1981, IBM unveiled its first personal computer, the IBM PC, helping bring computing to the masses.

08-13.title: Fall of the Aztec Empire
08-13.description: On August 13, 1521, Spanish conquistadors led by Hernán Cortés captured Aztec Emperor Cuauhtémoc, bringing the Aztec Empire to an end.

08-13.title: Tenbun Hokke Disturbance in Kyoto
08-13.description: On August 13, 1536, Buddhist monks from Kyoto's Enryaku-ji Temple set fire to 21 Nichiren temples throughout Kyoto.

08-13.title: Mars's Southern Polar Cap Discovered
08-13.description: On August 13, 1642, Dutch astronomer Christiaan Huygens discovered Mars's southern polar cap.

08-13.title: Triple Alliance Formed
08-13.description: On August 13, 1788, Prussia joined the Anglo-Dutch alliance to form the Triple Alliance to prevent the spread of the Russo-Swedish War.

08-13.title: Battle of Shanghai Begins
08-13.description: On August 13, 1937, Japanese forces began the Battle of Shanghai, a three-month conflict involving over one million troops.

08-13.title: Manhattan Project Commences
08-13.description: On August 13, 1942, the Manhattan Project commenced under the direction of U.S. General Leslie Groves with the aim of developing an atomic bomb.

08-14.title: Mongol Fleet Destroyed by Typhoon
08-14.description: On August 14, 1281, during Kublai Khan's second Mongol invasion of Japan, his invading Chinese fleet of 3,500 vessels was destroyed by a typhoon.

08-14.title: Second Seminole War Declared Over
08-14.description: On August 14, 1842, the U.S. Army declared the Second Seminole War over after nearly seven years. Over 3,000 surviving Seminoles were forcibly relocated.

08-14.title: V-J Day: Japan Surrenders
08-14.description: On August 14, 1945 (V-J Day), the Empire of Japan surrendered unconditionally to the Allies, ending World War II.

08-14.title: Pakistan Gains Independence
08-14.description: On August 14, 1947, Pakistan gained its independence from the United Kingdom.

08-14.title: Operation Banner Begins in Northern Ireland
08-14.description: On August 14, 1969, the British Army deployed on the streets of Northern Ireland, beginning Operation Banner.

08-14.title: Solidarity Movement Begins in Poland
08-14.description: On August 14, 1980, 17,000 workers went on strike at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdańsk, Poland, beginning the Solidarity movement.

08-15.title: Last Remnant of Byzantine Empire Falls
08-15.description: On August 15, 1461, the Empire of Trebizond surrendered to forces of Sultan Mehmed II, the last remnant of the Byzantine Empire to fall.

08-15.title: The Mayflower Sets Sail
08-15.description: On August 15, 1620, the Mayflower set sail from Southampton, England, with 102 Pilgrims bound for the New World.

08-15.title: Second U.S. National Women's Rights Convention
08-15.description: On August 15, 1851, the second U.S. National Women's Rights Convention convened in Worcester, Massachusetts.

08-15.title: Chinese Empress Dowager Cixi Flees Peking
08-15.description: On August 15, 1900, Chinese Empress Dowager Cixi and her court fled Peking as foreign troops moved in to quell the Boxer Rebellion.

08-15.title: India Gains Independence
08-15.description: On August 15, 1947, India gained its independence from the United Kingdom.

08-15.title: Omagh Bombing in Northern Ireland
08-15.description: On August 15, 1998, the Omagh bombing in Northern Ireland, the worst terrorist incident of The Troubles, killed 29 people and injured about 220.

08-15.title: Taliban Takes Control of Afghanistan
08-15.description: On August 15, 2021, Afghan President Ashraf Ghani fled the country as Taliban forces entered the capital Kabul and took control.

08-16.title: Battle of the Spurs
08-16.description: On August 16, 1513, at the Battle of the Spurs, King Henry VIII of England and Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I defeated French forces.

08-16.title: First Transatlantic Telegraph Message
08-16.description: On August 16, 1858, Britain's Queen Victoria telegraphed U.S. President James Buchanan for the first time via the new transatlantic cable.

08-16.title: Klondike Gold Rush Begins
08-16.description: On August 16, 1896, gold was first discovered in the Klondike at Bonanza Creek in Yukon, Canada, by George Carmack.

08-16.title: First British Empire Games Open
08-16.description: On August 16, 1930, the first British Empire Games (now the Commonwealth Games) opened in Hamilton, Canada.

08-16.title: Last Chinese Emperor Captured by Soviet Troops
08-16.description: On August 16, 1945, Puyi, the last Chinese Emperor and ruler of the Japanese puppet state Manchukuo, was captured by Soviet troops.

08-16.title: Direct Action Day Riots in Calcutta
08-16.description: On August 16, 1946, widespread riots erupted in Calcutta between Muslims and Hindus over whether Pakistan should be a separate state, killing over 4,000.

08-17.title: Pulitzer Prizes Established
08-17.description: On August 17, 1903, Joseph Pulitzer donated $1 million to Columbia University, leading to the establishment of the Pulitzer Prizes.

08-17.title: Korea Divided at 38th Parallel
08-17.description: On August 17, 1945, Korea was divided into North and South Korea along the 38th parallel following the end of World War II.

08-17.title: Indonesia Declares Independence
08-17.description: On August 17, 1945, Sukarno and Mohammad Hatta declared Indonesia independent from the Netherlands.

08-17.title: Radcliffe Line Revealed
08-17.description: On August 17, 1947, the Radcliffe Line was revealed, setting the border between the newly independent nations of India and Pakistan.

08-17.title: Clinton Admits to 'Improper Relationship' with Lewinsky
08-17.description: On August 17, 1998, U.S. President Bill Clinton admitted in taped testimony that he had an 'improper physical relationship' with intern Monica Lewinsky.

08-18.title: Lost Colony of Roanoke Discovered Empty
08-18.description: On August 18, 1590, John White, governor of the Roanoke Island colony, returned from England to find no trace of the colonists he had left there.

08-18.title: First Public Admission to Salon de Paris
08-18.description: On August 18, 1737, the first public admission to the Salon de Paris art exhibition was held at the Louvre in Paris.

08-18.title: U.S. Exploring Expedition Departs for Pacific
08-18.description: On August 18, 1838, the United States Exploring Expedition, headed by Charles Wilkes, departed for the Pacific Ocean and Antarctica.

08-18.title: Anti-Cigarette League of America Forms
08-18.description: On August 18, 1919, the Anti-Cigarette League of America formed in Chicago, Illinois.

08-18.title: 19th Amendment Ratified, Granting Women's Suffrage
08-18.description: On August 18, 1920, State Representative Harry T. Burn cast the deciding vote for Tennessee to ratify the 19th Amendment, granting women the right to vote.

08-18.title: Battle of Britain: 'The Hardest Day'
08-18.description: On August 18, 1940, during the Battle of Britain, an air battle known as 'The Hardest Day' occurred, with heavy losses on both sides.

08-19.title: Octavian Elected Consul
08-19.description: On August 19, 43 BC, Octavian, later known as Augustus, compelled the Roman Senate to elect him consul.

08-19.title: Daguerreotype Photographic Process Published
08-19.description: On August 19, 1839, Louis Daguerre's daguerreotype photographic process was published 'free to the world' as a gift from the French government.

08-19.title: Dieppe Raid
08-19.description: On August 19, 1942, during World War II, over 4,000 Canadian and British soldiers were killed, wounded, or captured during a raid on Dieppe, France.

08-19.title: Iran-Iraq War Ceasefire Begins
08-19.description: On August 19, 1988, Iran and Iraq began a ceasefire in their eight-year-old war.

08-19.title: Soviet Coup Attempt Against Gorbachev
08-19.description: On August 19, 1991, conservative members of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union attempted to depose Mikhail Gorbachev in a coup d'état.

08-19.title: Operation Iraqi Freedom Winds Down
08-19.description: On August 19, 2010, Operation Iraqi Freedom wound down as the last of the United States Brigade Combat Teams crossed the border into Kuwait.

08-20.title: First Dutch East India Company Ships Return
08-20.description: On August 20, 1597, the first Dutch East India Company ships returned from the Far East.

08-20.title: Alaska First Sighted by Europeans
08-20.description: On August 20, 1741, Alaska was first sighted by a Russian expedition led by Danish explorer Vitus Bering.

08-20.title: Sun Yat-sen Forms Tongmenghui
08-20.description: On August 20, 1905, Chinese revolutionary Sun Yat-sen formed the first chapter of Tongmenghui, a union of secret societies aimed at overthrowing the Qing dynasty.

08-20.title: Warsaw Pact Invasion of Czechoslovakia
08-20.description: On August 20, 1968, 250,000 Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops invaded Czechoslovakia to suppress the Prague Spring.

08-20.title: Oslo Peace Accords Signed
08-20.description: On August 20, 1993, the Oslo I Accord was signed between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization after secret negotiations in Norway.

08-21.title: Edirne Incident Ousts Ottoman Sultan
08-21.description: On August 21, 1703, in the Edirne Incident, the Turkish army ousted Sultan Mustafa II, replacing him with his brother Ahmed III.

08-21.title: King Gustav III's Coup d'État in Sweden
08-21.description: On August 21, 1772, King Gustav III of Sweden completed a coup d'état, ending fifty years of parliamentary rule and installing himself as an enlightened despot.

08-21.title: Adding Machine Patented
08-21.description: On August 21, 1888, American inventor William Seward Burroughs patented the adding machine.

08-21.title: Mona Lisa Stolen from the Louvre
08-21.description: On August 21, 1911, the Mona Lisa was stolen from the Louvre Museum by Vincenzo Peruggia; it was recovered in 1913.

08-21.title: Hawaii Becomes 50th U.S. State
08-21.description: On August 21, 1959, Hawaii became the 50th state of the United States.

08-21.title: Soviet Coup Crushed by Popular Resistance
08-21.description: On August 21, 1991, a conservative coup in the Soviet Union was crushed by popular resistance led by Boris Yeltsin.

08-22.title: Battle of Bosworth Field
08-22.description: On August 22, 1485, at the Battle of Bosworth Field, Henry Tudor's forces defeated English King Richard III, who was killed, ending the Wars of the Roses.

08-22.title: City of Madras (Chennai) Founded
08-22.description: On August 22, 1639, Madras (now Chennai), India, was founded by the British East India Company.

08-22.title: English Civil War Begins
08-22.description: On August 22, 1642, the English Civil War began between Royalists and Parliamentarians.

08-22.title: King George III Declares American Colonies in Rebellion
08-22.description: On August 22, 1775, King George III of Great Britain proclaimed the American colonies to be in open rebellion.

08-22.title: First Geneva Convention Adopted
08-22.description: On August 22, 1864, the First Geneva Convention, 'for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded in Armies in the Field,' was signed by 12 nations.

08-23.title: William Wallace Executed
08-23.description: On August 23, 1305, Scottish patriot William Wallace was executed for high treason by Edward I of England in London.

08-23.title: Rabbi Joseph Caro Completes 'Beit Yosef'
08-23.description: On August 23, 1542, Rabbi Joseph Caro completed his major work, the 'Beit Yosef,' a voluminous commentary on Jewish law.

08-23.title: Battle of Stalingrad: Luftwaffe Bombs City
08-23.description: On August 23, 1942, during the Battle of Stalingrad, 600 Luftwaffe planes bombed the city, killing 40,000 people.

08-23.title: Battle of Kursk Ends
08-23.description: On August 23, 1943, the Battle of Kursk, the largest tank battle in history, ended as the Soviet Union defeated Germany.

08-23.title: Osama bin Laden Issues Declaration of War
08-23.description: On August 23, 1996, Osama bin Laden issued a message entitled 'A Declaration of War Against the Americans Occupying the Land of the Two Holy Places'.

08-24.title: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius (Traditional Date)
08-24.description: August 24, 79 AD, was long believed to be the date of the massive eruption of Mt. Vesuvius that buried Pompeii, though recent evidence suggests it occurred in October.

08-24.title: Visigoths Sack Rome
08-24.description: On August 24, 410, Rome was overrun by Visigoths under Alaric I for the first time in nearly 800 years, an event seen as pivotal in the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

08-24.title: Battle of Marj Dabiq
08-24.description: On August 24, 1516, Ottoman forces decisively defeated the Mamluk Sultanate at the Battle of Marj Dabiq, ending Egyptian control in the Middle East.

08-24.title: St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre
08-24.description: On August 24, 1572, the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre of Protestants by Roman Catholics began in Paris.

08-24.title: Act of Uniformity Requires Use of Book of Common Prayer
08-24.description: On August 24, 1662, the Act of Uniformity required English government and church officials to accept the Book of Common Prayer.

08-24.title: British Forces Capture Washington, D.C.
08-24.description: On August 24, 1814, British forces captured Washington, D.C. during the War of 1812 and destroyed many landmarks, including the White House.

08-24.title: France Becomes Fifth Thermonuclear Power
08-24.description: On August 24, 1968, France became the world's fifth thermonuclear power with a detonation at Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific.

08-25.title: Galileo Demonstrates His Telescope
08-25.description: On August 25, 1609, Galileo Galilei demonstrated his first telescope to Venetian lawmakers.

08-25.title: First African Captives Arrive in Virginia
08-25.description: On August 25, 1619, the first known African captives (approximately 20) landed at Point Comfort, Virginia, marking the beginning of slavery in mainland British North America.

08-25.title: New Orleans Founded
08-25.description: On August 25, 1718, hundreds of French colonists arrived in Louisiana and founded New Orleans.

08-25.title: Captain Cook's First Voyage Departs
08-25.description: On August 25, 1768, Captain James Cook departed from Plymouth, England, on his first voyage aboard the Endeavour.

08-25.title: Bubonic Plague Agent Discovered
08-25.description: On August 25, 1894, Japanese scientist Shibasaburo Kitasato discovered the infectious agent of the bubonic plague.

08-25.title: Liberation of Paris
08-25.description: On August 25, 1944, German commander Dietrich von Choltitz surrendered Paris to Free French forces, disobeying Adolf Hitler's orders to destroy the city.

08-25.title: UN Authorizes Military Action Against Iraq
08-25.description: On August 25, 1990, the UN Security Council authorized military action against Iraq for invading Kuwait.

08-25.title: Linux Operating System Announced
08-25.description: On August 25, 1991, Linus Torvalds sent an email announcing his project to create a new computer operating system, which became Linux.

08-26.title: Battle of Crécy
08-26.description: On August 26, 1346, at the Battle of Crécy, Edward III's English longbows defeated Philip VI's larger French army. Cannons were used for the first time in a major European battle.

08-26.title: Edmond Halley Observes His Comet
08-26.description: On August 26, 1682, English astronomer Edmond Halley first observed the comet that would later be named after him.

08-26.title: First Free Kindergarten in U.S. Started
08-26.description: On August 26, 1873, the first free kindergarten in the United States was started by Susan Blow in Carondelet, a suburb of St. Louis, Missouri.

08-26.title: Nationalist Troops Conquer Santander
08-26.description: On August 26, 1937, General Franco's Nationalist troops conquered Santander during the Spanish Civil War.

08-26.title: Classic Mini Car Introduced
08-26.description: On August 26, 1959, the British Motor Corporation introduced the Morris Mini-Minor, an iconic car designed by Alec Issigonis.

08-26.title: U.S. President Clinton Signs Welfare Reform
08-26.description: On August 26, 1996, U.S. President Bill Clinton signed welfare reform into law, representing a major shift in welfare policy.

08-27.title: Battle of Mycale
08-27.description: On August 27, 479 BC, during the Greco-Persian Wars, Greek forces won the Battle of Mycale over Persian naval troops on the Ionian coast.

08-27.title: Battle of Plataea
08-27.description: On August 27, 479 BC, a Greek army under Pausanias routed Persian forces at the Battle of Plataea, ending the Persian invasion.

08-27.title: Battle of Baekgang
08-27.description: On August 27, 663, Tang Chinese and Silla Korean forces defeated Baekje Korean and Yamato Japanese forces at the Battle of Baekgang.

08-27.title: Declaration of the Rights of Man Issued
08-27.description: On August 27, 1789, the French National Assembly issued the 'Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen'.

08-27.title: Krakatoa Volcano Erupts
08-27.description: On August 27, 1883, the Krakatoa volcano in Indonesia erupted with immense force, killing approximately 36,000 people.

08-27.title: Kellogg-Briand Pact Signed
08-27.description: On August 27, 1928, in the Kellogg-Briand Pact, 60 nations agreed to condemn 'recourse to war for the solution of international controversies'.

08-27.title: Lord Mountbatten Assassinated
08-27.description: On August 27, 1979, Lord Mountbatten, cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, was killed by the IRA when his boat was blown up near Sligo, Ireland.

08-27.title: Barack Obama Nominated for President
08-27.description: On August 27, 2008, U.S. Senator Barack Obama became the first African American to be nominated by a major political party for President of the United States.

08-28.title: Third Crusade: Siege of Acre Begins
08-28.description: On August 28, 1189, during the Third Crusade, Crusaders began the Siege of Acre under Guy of Lusignan.

08-28.title: Liverpool Granted a Royal Charter
08-28.description: On August 28, 1207, King John of England granted the small town of Liverpool a charter.

08-28.title: Henry Hudson Sails into Delaware Bay
08-28.description: On August 28, 1609, English explorer Henry Hudson became the first European to sail into Delaware Bay.

08-28.title: First American-Built Locomotive Races a Horse
08-28.description: On August 28, 1830, the first American-built locomotive, 'Tom Thumb,' raced a horse-drawn car. Due to mechanical problems, the horse won.

08-28.title: Scientific American Publishes First Issue
08-28.description: On August 28, 1845, Scientific American magazine published its first issue.

08-28.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Delivers 'I Have a Dream' Speech
08-28.description: On August 28, 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his 'I Have a Dream' speech during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

08-29.title: Battle of Mohács
08-29.description: On August 29, 1526, at the Battle of Mohács, the Kingdom of Hungary was conquered by the Ottoman Empire led by Suleiman the Magnificent.

08-29.title: Portugal Recognizes Brazil's Independence
08-29.description: On August 29, 1825, Portugal recognized the independence of its former colony Brazil.

08-29.title: Treaty of Nanking Ends First Opium War
08-29.description: On August 29, 1842, the United Kingdom and China signed the Treaty of Nanking, ending the First Opium War.

08-29.title: Second Battle of Bull Run
08-29.description: On August 29, 1862, the Second Battle of Bull Run began in Manassas, Virginia, leading to a Confederate victory.

08-29.title: Soviet Union's First Nuclear Weapons Test
08-29.description: On August 29, 1949, the Soviet Union secretly performed its first successful nuclear weapons test.

08-29.title: Hurricane Katrina Makes Landfall
08-29.description: On August 29, 2005, Hurricane Katrina made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane, devastating much of the U.S. Gulf Coast and killing more than 1,800 people.

08-30.title: European Leaders Outlaw the Crossbow
08-30.description: On August 30, 1146, European leaders outlawed the crossbow, wrongly believing it would end war for all time.

08-30.title: Battle of Lake Poyang
08-30.description: On August 30, 1363, the Battle of Lake Poyang began, one of the largest naval battles in history, between two Chinese rebel leaders.

08-30.title: Tokugawa Ieyasu Enters Edo Castle
08-30.description: On August 30, 1590, Tokugawa Ieyasu entered Edo Castle, which would become the center of his shogunate.

08-30.title: William Penn Sails to the New World
08-30.description: On August 30, 1682, William Penn left England to sail to the New World to establish the colony of Pennsylvania.

08-30.title: Second Battle of Bull Run Ends
08-30.description: On August 30, 1862, the Second Battle of Bull Run in Manassas, Virginia, ended with a Confederate victory over Union forces.

08-30.title: Battle of Tannenberg Ends
08-30.description: On August 30, 1914, the Battle of Tannenberg in East Prussia ended in the destruction of the Russian Second Army by German forces.

08-30.title: Nehru Report Submitted
08-30.description: On August 30, 1928, Jawaharlal Nehru submitted the Nehru Report, requesting independence for India and outlining a proposed constitution.

08-31.title: Possible Date for Iroquois League Establishment
08-31.description: August 31, 1142 is one possible date for the establishment of the Iroquois (Haudenosaunee) League, though other research suggests later dates.

08-31.title: Soho Cholera Outbreak
08-31.description: On August 31, 1854, a major outbreak of cholera began in Soho, London. Physician John Snow later traced its source to a contaminated water pump.

08-31.title: Jack the Ripper's First Victim Found
08-31.description: On August 31, 1888, the body of Mary Ann Nichols, Jack the Ripper's first confirmed victim, was found in Whitechapel, London.

08-31.title: Sun Yat-sen Establishes Military Government in China
08-31.description: On August 31, 1917, Sun Yat-sen and his supporters' parliament established a military government in China and elected Sun as Commander-in-Chief.

08-31.title: Liberal Party of Australia Founded
08-31.description: On August 31, 1945, the Liberal Party of Australia was founded by Robert Menzies.

08-31.title: Malaya Gains Independence
08-31.description: On August 31, 1957, the Federation of Malaya gained independence from Great Britain.

08-31.title: Provisional IRA Declares Ceasefire
08-31.description: On August 31, 1994, the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) declared a ceasefire in Northern Ireland.

08-31.title: Princess Diana Dies in Car Crash
08-31.description: On August 31, 1997, Diana, Princess of Wales, died in a car crash in a road tunnel in Paris.

09-01.title: King Louis XIV of France Dies
09-01.description: On September 1, 1715, King Louis XIV of France died after a reign of 72 years, the longest of any major European monarch.

09-01.title: First Female Telephone Operator
09-01.description: On September 1, 1878, Emma Nutt began work as the first female telephone operator for the Edwin Holmes Telephone Dispatch Company in Boston.

09-01.title: Alberta and Saskatchewan Join Canada
09-01.description: On September 1, 1905, Alberta and Saskatchewan joined the Confederation of Canada as its 8th and 9th provinces.

09-01.title: World War II Begins
09-01.description: On September 1, 1939, World War II began when Germany invaded Poland.

09-01.title: Jews in Germany Required to Wear Star of David
09-01.description: On September 1, 1941, all Jews living in Germany were required to wear a yellow Star of David.

09-01.title: ANZUS Treaty Signed
09-01.description: On September 1, 1951, the U.S., Australia, and New Zealand signed the ANZUS mutual defense treaty.

09-01.title: Muammar Gaddafi Seizes Power in Libya
09-01.description: On September 1, 1969, Colonel Muammar Gaddafi deposed King Idris in the Libyan Revolution.

09-02.title: Battle of Actium
09-02.description: On September 2, 31 BC, at the Battle of Actium, Octavian's forces defeated those under Mark Antony and Cleopatra, effectively ending the Roman Republic.

09-02.title: Treaty of Jaffa Ends Third Crusade
09-02.description: On September 2, 1192, Sultan Saladin and King Richard the Lionheart signed the Treaty of Jaffa, ending the Third Crusade.

09-02.title: Great Fire of London Begins
09-02.description: On September 2, 1666, the Great Fire of London began at 2am in Pudding Lane; it eventually destroyed 80% of the city.

09-02.title: September Massacres of the French Revolution
09-02.description: On September 2, 1792, during the September Massacres, rampaging mobs in Paris slaughtered priests and prisoners believed to be royalist sympathizers.

09-02.title: Union General Sherman Captures Atlanta
09-02.description: On September 2, 1864, Union General William T. Sherman captured and occupied Atlanta, Georgia, a major turning point in the U.S. Civil War.

09-03.title: San Marino Founded
09-03.description: On September 3, 301, San Marino, one of the world's smallest nations and its oldest republic, was founded by Saint Marinus.

09-03.title: Battle of Dunbar
09-03.description: On September 3, 1650, Oliver Cromwell's English New Model Army defeated a Scottish force in a surprise attack at the Battle of Dunbar.

09-03.title: Treaty of Paris Ends American Revolutionary War
09-03.description: On September 3, 1783, the Treaty of Paris was signed, ending the American Revolutionary War between Great Britain and the United States.

09-03.title: French Constitution of 1791 Passed
09-03.description: On September 3, 1791, the new French Constitution, declaring France a constitutional monarchy, was passed by the National Assembly.

09-03.title: Britain Annexes Boer Republic of South Africa
09-03.description: On September 3, 1900, Britain annexed the Boer Republic of South Africa with a proclamation by General Lord Roberts.

09-03.title: Alexander Fleming Discovers Penicillin
09-03.description: On September 3, 1928, Scottish bacteriologist Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin at St. Mary's Hospital in London.

09-03.title: Britain and France Declare War on Germany
09-03.description: On September 3, 1939, Britain and France declared war on Germany following the invasion of Poland.

09-03.title: Anne Frank Sent to Auschwitz
09-03.description: On September 3, 1944, Holocaust diarist Anne Frank was among the prisoners on the final transport of Dutch Jews sent from Westerbork to Auschwitz.

09-03.title: Sweden Switches to Driving on the Right
09-03.description: On September 3, 1967, Sweden switched to driving on the right-hand side of the road (an event known as Dagen H).

09-03.title: Iraq Kills 50,000 Kurds
09-03.description: By September 3, 1988, an estimated 50,000 Kurdish civilians and soldiers had been killed by Iraq, many with chemical weapons, in the Anfal campaign.

09-04.title: End of the Western Roman Empire
09-04.description: On September 4, 476, Romulus Augustulus, the last Western Roman Emperor, abdicated after Odoacer's forces invaded Rome.

09-04.title: Henry Hudson Discovers Manhattan
09-04.description: On September 4, 1609, navigator Henry Hudson became the first European to enter the river that now bears his name, discovering the island of Manhattan.

09-04.title: Los Angeles Founded
09-04.description: On September 4, 1781, Los Angeles was founded by 44 Spanish-speaking settlers in what was then Spanish territory.

09-04.title: Confederate General Lee Invades the North
09-04.description: On September 4, 1862, General Robert E. Lee began the Maryland Campaign, invading the North with 50,000 Confederate troops.

09-04.title: Little Rock Crisis Begins
09-04.description: On September 4, 1957, the governor of Arkansas called out the National Guard to prevent nine Black students from entering Little Rock Central High School.

09-05.title: Great Fire of London Brought Under Control
09-05.description: On September 5, 1666, firebreaks finally brought the Great Fire of London under control, leaving 13,200 houses destroyed.

09-05.title: First Continental Congress Adopts Trade Embargo
09-05.description: On September 5, 1774, the First Continental Congress adopted a trade embargo against Great Britain in Philadelphia.

09-05.title: Battle of the Chesapeake
09-05.description: On September 5, 1781, a French fleet defeated British forces at the Battle of the Chesapeake, a decisive naval victory in the American Revolutionary War.

09-05.title: First Opium War Begins
09-05.description: On September 5, 1839, the First Opium War began between the British Empire and the Qing dynasty of China.

09-05.title: First Color Video Recording on Magnetic Tape
09-05.description: On September 5, 1958, the first color video recording on magnetic tape was presented in Charlotte, North Carolina.

09-05.title: Hurricane Irma Becomes Powerful Atlantic Hurricane
09-05.description: On September 5, 2017, Hurricane Irma became one of the most powerful hurricanes ever recorded in the Atlantic Basin, with winds of 185 mph (280 km/h).

09-06.title: First Circumnavigation of the Globe Completed
09-06.description: On September 6, 1522, Ferdinand Magellan's Spanish expedition, led by Juan Sebastián Elcano after Magellan's death, returned to Seville, becoming the first to circumnavigate the globe.

09-06.title: Great Fire of London Extinguished
09-06.description: On September 6, 1666, after St. Paul's Cathedral and much of the city had burned, the Great Fire of London was finally extinguished.

09-06.title: U.S. President William McKinley Assassinated
09-06.description: On September 6, 1901, US President William McKinley was shot by anarchist Leon Czolgosz; he died eight days later.

09-06.title: Robert Peary Claims Discovery of North Pole
09-06.description: On September 6, 1909, a New York Times headline announced American explorer Robert Peary had discovered the North Pole 5 months earlier (a claim now disputed).

09-06.title: First Battle of the Marne Begins
09-06.description: On September 6, 1914, the First Battle of the Marne began, as French and British forces prevented the German advance on Paris.

09-07.title: Treaty of Baden Signed
09-07.description: On September 7, 1714, the Treaty of Baden was signed by the Holy Roman Empire and France, ending the War of the Spanish Succession.

09-07.title: Battle of Borodino
09-07.description: On September 7, 1812, Napoleon Bonaparte won a Pyrrhic victory against the Russian army in the Battle of Borodino, the most ferocious battle of the Napoleonic era.

09-07.title: Brazil Declares Independence
09-07.description: On September 7, 1822, Pedro I declared Brazil's independence from Portugal.

09-07.title: First Baby Placed in an Incubator
09-07.description: On September 7, 1888, Edith Eleanor McLean became the first baby placed in an incubator at State Emigrant Hospital on Ward's Island, New York.

09-07.title: First Pilot to Die in an Aircraft
09-07.description: On September 7, 1909, Eugene Lefebvre became the first pilot to die in an aircraft while test piloting a new French-built Wright biplane.

09-07.title: The Blitz Begins
09-07.description: On September 7, 1940, the Blitz began as the German Luftwaffe bombed London for the first of 57 consecutive nights.

09-08.title: Roman Army Destroys Jerusalem
09-08.description: On September 8, 70, the Roman army under General Titus completed the siege of Jerusalem by destroying the Second Temple and the rest of the city.

09-08.title: Battle of Kulikovo
09-08.description: On September 8, 1380, at the Battle of Kulikovo, Moscow's monarch Dmitry Donskoy defeated the Mongols, beginning the decline of the Golden Horde.

09-08.title: Michelangelo's 'David' Unveiled
09-08.description: On September 8, 1504, Michelangelo's statue of David was unveiled in Florence.

09-08.title: First Permanent European Settlement in U.S. Founded
09-08.description: On September 8, 1565, the first permanent European settlement in the U.S. was founded in St. Augustine, Florida.

09-08.title: Dutch Surrender New Netherland to English
09-08.description: On September 8, 1664, the Dutch surrendered the colony of New Netherland, including New Amsterdam (now New York), to 300 English soldiers.

09-08.title: Siege of Leningrad Begins
09-08.description: On September 8, 1941, the Siege of Leningrad by German, Finnish, and Spanish troops began. The battle lasted over 28 months, with well over a million lives lost.

09-08.title: Black September Hijackings
09-08.description: On September 8, 1970, the Black September hijackings began as three airliners were hijacked and later destroyed by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

09-08.title: Queen Elizabeth II Dies
09-08.description: On September 8, 2022, Queen Elizabeth II died at Balmoral Castle after ruling for 70 years as the UK's longest-serving monarch. Her eldest son inherited the throne as King Charles III.

09-09.title: Battle of Svolder
09-09.description: On September 9, 1000, in one of the greatest naval battles of the Viking Age, King Olaf of Norway was defeated and leapt to his death at the Battle of Svolder.

09-09.title: Mary, Queen of Scots, Crowned
09-09.description: On September 9, 1543, Mary Stuart, at nine months old, was crowned Queen of Scots in Stirling.

09-09.title: U.S. Officially Named
09-09.description: On September 9, 1776, the Continental Congress officially renamed the country as the United States of America (from the United Colonies).

09-09.title: First African American College Graduate in U.S.
09-09.description: On September 9, 1823, Alexander Twilight, likely the first African American to graduate from a U.S. college, received a BA degree from Middlebury College.

09-09.title: First Fully Mechanized Unit in British Army Created
09-09.description: On September 9, 1914, the first fully mechanized unit in the British Army was created: the Canadian Automobile Machine Gun Brigade.

09-09.title: Israel and PLO Exchange Letters of Recognition
09-09.description: On September 9, 1993, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization exchanged letters of mutual recognition.

09-09.title: Queen Elizabeth II Becomes Britain's Longest-Reigning Monarch
09-09.description: On September 9, 2015, Queen Elizabeth II became Great Britain's longest-reigning monarch, surpassing the record set by her great-great-grandmother, Queen Victoria.

09-10.title: Nathan Hale Volunteers as a Spy
09-10.description: On September 10, 1776, after George Washington asked for a spy to gather intelligence, Captain Nathan Hale volunteered.

09-10.title: Battle of Lake Erie
09-10.description: On September 10, 1813, American naval commander Oliver Hazard Perry defeated the British in the Battle of Lake Erie during the War of 1812.

09-10.title: Elias Howe Patents Lockstitch Sewing Machine
09-10.description: On September 10, 1846, Elias Howe was granted a U.S. patent for a lockstitch sewing machine.

09-10.title: Leopold and Loeb Found Guilty
09-10.description: On September 10, 1924, Leopold and Loeb were found guilty of the murder of Bobby Franks in Chicago in what was called 'the crime of the century'.

09-10.title: Last Person Executed by Guillotine in France
09-10.description: On September 10, 1977, Hamida Djandoubi, convicted of torture and murder, became the last person to be executed by guillotine in France.

09-10.title: Large Hadron Collider Powered Up
09-10.description: On September 10, 2008, the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, described as the biggest scientific experiment in history, was powered up in Geneva, Switzerland.

09-10.title: California's August Complex Becomes Largest Wildfire
09-10.description: On September 10, 2020, California's August Complex wildfire became the largest recorded in state history at 471,000 acres.

09-11.title: Battle of Stirling Bridge
09-11.description: On September 11, 1297, at the Battle of Stirling Bridge, Scottish rebel William Wallace led his forces to a victory over the English.

09-11.title: Expulsion of Moriscos from Spain
09-11.description: On September 11, 1609, an expulsion order was issued against the Moriscos of Valencia, beginning the expulsion of all of Spain's Moriscos.

09-11.title: Battle of Zenta
09-11.description: On September 11, 1697, Holy League forces led by Prince Eugene of Savoy defeated an Ottoman army at the Battle of Zenta, ending Ottoman control over large parts of Central Europe.

09-11.title: Great Northern War Turning Point
09-11.description: On September 11, 1708, Charles XII of Sweden stopped his march to conquer Moscow, a turning point in the Great Northern War.

09-11.title: First True Self-Service Supermarket Opens
09-11.description: On September 11, 1916, the first true self-service supermarket, Clarence Saunders' 'Piggly Wiggly,' opened in Memphis, Tennessee.

09-11.title: 9/11: United Airlines Flight 93 Crashes
09-11.description: On September 11, 2001, passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 attempted to retake control of their hijacked plane, causing it to crash in a Pennsylvania field.

09-11.title: 9/11: Attack on the Pentagon
09-11.description: On September 11, 2001, terrorists hijacked a passenger plane and crashed it into the Pentagon, killing 125 people.

09-11.title: 9/11: Attack on World Trade Center
09-11.description: On September 11, 2001, two passenger planes hijacked by Al-Qaeda terrorists crashed into New York's World Trade Center towers, causing their collapse and the deaths of 2,606 people in the towers and on the ground.

09-12.title: First Submarine Publicly Tested
09-12.description: On September 12, 1624, the first submarine was publicly tested in London on the River Thames for King James I.

09-12.title: Charles Messier Begins His Catalog
09-12.description: On September 12, 1758, French astronomer Charles Messier mistook the Crab Nebula for a comet, leading him to begin his Messier Catalogue of celestial objects.

09-12.title: First Patent for Synthetic Rubber
09-12.description: On September 12, 1909, the world's first patent for synthetic rubber was granted to German chemist Fritz Hofmann.

09-12.title: Lascaux Cave Paintings Discovered
09-12.description: On September 12, 1940, four teenagers followed their dog down a hole near Lascaux, France, and discovered 17,000-year-old cave paintings.

09-12.title: Supreme Court Orders Little Rock School Integration
09-12.description: On September 12, 1958, the U.S. Supreme Court ordered the all-white Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, to integrate.

09-12.title: First Spacecraft to Impact the Moon
09-12.description: On September 12, 1959, Luna 2 was launched by the Soviet Union, becoming the first spacecraft to reach the surface of the Moon.

09-13.title: Temple of Jupiter Dedicated in Rome
09-13.description: On September 13, 509 BC, the Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus on Rome's Capitoline Hill was dedicated.

09-13.title: Church of the Holy Sepulchre Consecrated
09-13.description: On September 13, 335, the Church of the Holy Sepulchre was consecrated in Jerusalem.

09-13.title: Francis of Assisi Receives Stigmata
09-13.description: On September 13, 1224, Francis of Assisi is said to have received the stigmata after a vision while praying on Mount La Verna.

09-13.title: Michelangelo Begins Work on 'David'
09-13.description: On September 13, 1501, Michelangelo began work on his statue of David, a masterpiece of Renaissance sculpture.

09-13.title: Grand Assault on Gibraltar Defeated
09-13.description: On September 13, 1782, the Grand Assault on Gibraltar by allied French and Spanish fleets was heavily defeated by the British garrison.

09-13.title: Faraday Effect Discovered
09-13.description: On September 13, 1845, English chemist Michael Faraday discovered the 'Faraday effect,' the influence of a magnetic field on polarized light.

09-13.title: Battle of Chapultepec
09-13.description: On September 13, 1847, American forces captured Chapultepec Castle during the Mexican–American War, allowing them to take Mexico City.

09-13.title: Oslo Accords Publicly Unveiled
09-13.description: On September 13, 1993, the Oslo Accords, an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, were publicly unveiled with a signing ceremony in Washington, D.C.

09-14.title: Britain Adopts Gregorian Calendar
09-14.description: On September 14, 1752, Britain and its colonies adopted the Gregorian Calendar, skipping 11 days to sync with the solar year.

09-14.title: Burning of Smyrna
09-14.description: On September 14, 1922, the Ottoman army expelled Greeks and other non-Turks from Asia Minor, destroying much of the port city of Smyrna.

09-14.title: First Prefrontal Lobotomy in America
09-14.description: On September 14, 1936, the first prefrontal lobotomy in America was performed by Walter Freeman and James W. Watts at George Washington University Hospital.

09-14.title: First Practical Helicopter Flight
09-14.description: On September 14, 1939, the world's first practical helicopter, the VS-300 designed by Igor Sikorsky, took a short tethered flight.

09-14.title: Hindi Adopted as Official Language of India
09-14.description: On September 14, 1949, India's Constituent Assembly adopted Hindi as an official language, a day now celebrated as Hindi Day.

09-14.title: First Commercial Computer with Hard Drive
09-14.description: On September 14, 1956, IBM introduced the RAMAC 305, the first commercial computer with a hard drive, which weighed over a ton.

09-14.title: OPEC Formed
09-14.description: On September 14, 1960, Iraq, Iran, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and Venezuela formed the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).

09-14.title: Possible Sign of Life on Venus Reported
09-14.description: On September 14, 2020, astronomers reported a possible sign of life on Venus after detecting phosphine in the planet's atmosphere.

09-14.title: COVID-19 Death Toll Milestone in U.S.
09-14.description: On September 14, 2021, it was reported that one in 500 Americans had died of COVID-19, with the nation's known death toll reaching 663,913.

09-15.title: First Free Public School in Europe Opens
09-15.description: On September 15, 1616, the first non-aristocratic, free public school in Europe opened in Frascati, Italy.

09-15.title: Central American Independence
09-15.description: On September 15, 1821, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua declared their independence from the Spanish Empire.

09-15.title: Charles Darwin Reaches Galápagos Islands
09-15.description: On September 15, 1835, HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, reached the Galápagos Islands.

09-15.title: First Use of Tanks in Warfare
09-15.description: On September 15, 1916, tanks were first used in warfare by the British at the Battle of Flers-Courcelette during the Battle of the Somme.

09-15.title: Battle of Britain Day
09-15.description: On September 15, 1940, the Royal Air Force repulsed a major Luftwaffe attack, a day now known as Battle of Britain Day, marking a turning point in the air campaign.

09-15.title: George Soros 'Breaks the Bank of England'
09-15.description: On September 15, 1992, George Soros began selling large amounts of pound sterling, helping force the pound out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism and earning him the label 'the man who broke the Bank of England'.

09-16.title: Mayflower Departs for the New World
09-16.description: On September 16, 1620, the Mayflower departed Plymouth, England, with 102 Pilgrims and about 30 crew for the New World.

09-16.title: British Capture Cape Town
09-16.description: On September 16, 1795, the British captured Cape Town, South Africa, from the Dutch.

09-16.title: Mexican War of Independence Begins
09-16.description: On September 16, 1810, priest Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla issued the 'Grito de Dolores' (Cry of Dolores), calling for the end of Spanish rule and beginning the Mexican War of Independence.

09-16.title: Slavery Abolished in French Territories
09-16.description: On September 16, 1848, slavery was abolished in all French territories.

09-16.title: Wall Street Bombing
09-16.description: On September 16, 1920, the 'Wall Street bombing' occurred when a horse-drawn wagon exploded on Wall Street, New York, killing 38 and injuring 143.

09-16.title: Federation of Malaysia Formed
09-16.description: On September 16, 1963, the Federation of Malaysia was formed by Malaya, Singapore, British North Borneo (Sabah) and Sarawak.

09-16.title: Steve Jobs Named Interim CEO of Apple
09-16.description: On September 16, 1997, Apple Computer Inc. named co-founder Steve Jobs as interim CEO.

09-17.title: Arab Forces Conquer Alexandria
09-17.description: On September 17, 642, Arab forces under Amr ibn al-'As conquered Alexandria from the Byzantine Empire.

09-17.title: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek Reports Existence of Bacteria
09-17.description: On September 17, 1683, Dutch scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek was the first to report the existence of bacteria.

09-17.title: U.S. Constitution Signed
09-17.description: On September 17, 1787, the U.S. Constitution was signed by delegates at the Philadelphia Convention.

09-17.title: Battle of Antietam
09-17.description: On September 17, 1862, the Battle of Antietam became the bloodiest single day in the American Civil War, with 22,000 casualties.

09-17.title: The Red Baron's First Aerial Combat Victory
09-17.description: On September 17, 1916, World War I flying ace Manfred von Richthofen, the Red Baron, won his first aerial combat near Cambrai, France.

09-17.title: Hitler Postpones Invasion of Britain
09-17.description: On September 17, 1940, Adolf Hitler indefinitely postponed Operation Sealion, the planned German invasion of Great Britain.

09-17.title: Camp David Accords Signed
09-17.description: On September 17, 1978, Anwar Sadat, Menachem Begin, and Jimmy Carter signed the Camp David Accords, frameworks for peace in the Middle East.

09-18.title: British East India Company Conquers Java
09-18.description: On September 18, 1811, a British East India Company force conquered Java, then part of the Dutch East Indies.

09-18.title: Great Fire of Moscow Burns Out
09-18.description: On September 18, 1812, the Great Fire of Moscow burned out after five days, destroying 75% of the city.

09-18.title: Panic of 1873 Begins
09-18.description: On September 18, 1873, the collapse of banking firm Jay Cooke & Co caused panic on Wall Street, starting the Panic of 1873 and the Long Depression.

09-18.title: Irish Home Rule Bill Receives Royal Assent
09-18.description: On September 18, 1914, the Irish Home Rule Bill received Royal Assent, though its implementation was delayed by World War I.

09-18.title: Mukden Incident
09-18.description: On September 18, 1931, Japanese forces staged the Mukden Incident, a false flag event used as a pretext for the invasion of Manchuria.

09-18.title: Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Begins Operations
09-18.description: On September 18, 1947, the Central Intelligence Agency officially came into existence.

09-18.title: Mao Zedong's Funeral
09-18.description: On September 18, 1976, Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong's funeral took place in Beijing, China.

09-19.title: Battle of Poitiers
09-19.description: On September 19, 1356, English forces under Edward the Black Prince defeated the French and captured King John II at the Battle of Poitiers.

09-19.title: Siege of Paris Begins
09-19.description: On September 19, 1870, the Siege of Paris by Prussian forces began, lasting until January 28, 1871.

09-19.title: New Zealand Grants Women the Right to Vote
09-19.description: On September 19, 1893, New Zealand became the first country to grant all women the right to vote.

09-19.title: Mexico City Earthquake
09-19.description: On September 19, 1985, a magnitude 8.0 earthquake rocked Mexico City, killing an estimated 10,000 people.

09-19.title: First Antiretroviral Medication for HIV/AIDS Announced
09-19.description: On September 19, 1986, U.S. federal health officials announced that the first antiretroviral medication (AZT) would be available to patients.

09-20.title: Prophet Muhammad Arrives in Medina
09-20.description: On September 20, 622, the Islamic Prophet Muhammad arrived in Yathrib (now Medina) after his migration from Mecca.

09-20.title: Magellan's Circumnavigation Expedition Sets Off
09-20.description: On September 20, 1519, a Spanish expedition led by Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan set off on the first successful circumnavigation of the globe.

09-20.title: Siege of Ostend Ends
09-20.description: On September 20, 1604, the Siege of Ostend ended after three years, one of the bloodiest sieges in history with an estimated 100,000 casualties.

09-20.title: Battle of the Alma
09-20.description: On September 20, 1854, an allied British, French, and Ottoman force defeated the Russian Empire in the first major battle of the Crimean War.

09-20.title: Unification of Italy Completed
09-20.description: On September 20, 1870, Rome was captured by the Italian army, completing the unification of Italy and ending the 1,116-year reign of the Papal States.

09-20.title: East and West Germany Ratify Reunification
09-20.description: On September 20, 1990, East Germany and West Germany both ratified their reunification plan.

09-20.title: President Bush Declares 'War on Terror'
09-20.description: On September 20, 2001, in an address to Congress, US President George W. Bush declared a 'war on terror'.

09-20.title: World's Largest-Ever Climate Protest
09-20.description: On September 20, 2019, students from 185 countries staged the world's largest-ever protest on climate change.

09-21.title: Royal Charter to Colonize Nova Scotia
09-21.description: On September 21, 1621, King James I of England gave Scottish courtier William Alexander a royal charter to colonize Nova Scotia.

09-21.title: French First Republic Formed
09-21.description: On September 21, 1792, the French First Republic was formed by the National Convention, stripping the king of his powers.

09-21.title: French Monarchy Formally Abolished
09-21.description: On September 21, 1792, the National Convention passed a proclamation announcing the formal abolition of the French monarchy.

09-21.title: Hundred Days' Reform in China Ends
09-21.description: On September 21, 1898, Empress Dowager Cixi seized power and ended the Hundred Days' Reform in China.

09-21.title: Stonehenge Purchased and Donated to Britain
09-21.description: On September 21, 1915, Cecil Chubb bought the prehistoric monument Stonehenge for £6,600 and later donated it to the British nation.

09-21.title: U.S. Approves Jewish Homeland in Palestine
09-21.description: On September 21, 1922, US President Warren G. Harding signed a joint resolution of approval to establish a Jewish homeland in Palestine.

09-21.title: Francisco Franco Named Generalísimo
09-21.description: On September 21, 1936, the Spanish fascist junta named Francisco Franco Generalísimo and Supreme Commander.

09-21.title: People's Republic of China Announced
09-21.description: On September 21, 1949, Mao Zedong and Chinese Communist leaders announced the establishment of the People's Republic of China.

09-22.title: Last Hangings of Salem Witch Trials
09-22.description: On September 22, 1692, the last eight people were hanged for allegedly practicing witchcraft during the Salem witch trials in Massachusetts.

09-22.title: Lincoln Issues Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation
09-22.description: On September 22, 1862, US President Abraham Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, which would take effect on January 1, 1863.

09-22.title: Indo-Pakistani War Ceasefire
09-22.description: On September 22, 1965, a ceasefire between India and Pakistan went into effect, ending the Indo-Pakistani War.

09-22.title: Iran-Iraq War Begins
09-22.description: On September 22, 1980, Iraq invaded Iran in an attempt to control the Shatt al-Arab waterway, beginning the Iran-Iraq War.

09-23.title: Concordat of Worms Agreed
09-23.description: On September 23, 1122, the Concordat of Worms was agreed upon between Pope Calixtus II and Holy Roman Emperor Henry V, ending the Investiture Controversy.

09-23.title: Fall of Tripolitsa Massacre
09-23.description: On September 23, 1821, Greek forces massacred thousands of Muslim and Jewish civilians in the Fall of Tripolitsa during the Greek War of Independence.

09-23.title: Otto von Bismarck Appointed Prime Minister of Prussia
09-23.description: On September 23, 1862, Otto von Bismarck was appointed Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Prussia by King Wilhelm I.

09-23.title: Mechanical Tabulating Machine Patented
09-23.description: On September 23, 1884, American Herman Hollerith patented his mechanical tabulating machine, a key invention in the history of data processing.

09-23.title: Eisenhower Orders Troops to Little Rock
09-23.description: On September 23, 1957, President Dwight D. Eisenhower ordered U.S. troops to support the integration of nine Black students at Little Rock Central High School.

09-23.title: India Launches 'Modicare' Healthcare Program
09-23.description: On September 23, 2018, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi launched 'Modicare,' a free healthcare program for 500 million people.

09-24.title: Decline of the Byzantine Empire
09-24.description: On September 24, 1180, with the death of Manuel I Komnenos, the Byzantine Empire began its terminal decline.

09-24.title: Christopher Columbus's Second Expedition
09-24.description: On September 24, 1493, Christopher Columbus embarked on his second expedition to the New World with a fleet of 17 ships.

09-24.title: U.S. Federal Judiciary Act Passes
09-24.description: On September 24, 1789, the U.S. Federal Judiciary Act was passed, creating a six-member Supreme Court.

09-24.title: Black Friday on Wall Street
09-24.description: On September 24, 1869, panic erupted on Wall Street after investors Jay Gould and James Fisk attempted to corner the gold market.

09-24.title: Battle of Shiroyama
09-24.description: On September 24, 1877, the Imperial Japanese Army decisively defeated the Satsuma Rebellion at the Battle of Shiroyama.

09-24.title: Operation Magic Carpet Concludes
09-24.description: On September 24, 1950, Operation Magic Carpet concluded after transporting 45,000 Yemenite Jews to Israel.

09-25.title: Battle of Stamford Bridge
09-25.description: On September 25, 1066, the English army under King Harold II defeated invading Norwegians at the Battle of Stamford Bridge.

09-25.title: Treaty of York Signed
09-25.description: On September 25, 1237, the Treaty of York was signed between England and Scotland, establishing a boundary that remains largely unchanged today.

09-25.title: Balboa Sights the Pacific Ocean
09-25.description: On September 25, 1513, Spanish explorer Vasco Núñez de Balboa crossed the Isthmus of Panama, becoming the first European to see the Pacific Ocean from the Americas.

09-25.title: U.S. Congress Proposes Bill of Rights
09-25.description: On September 25, 1789, the First U.S. Congress proposed the Bill of Rights, a set of amendments guaranteeing essential liberties.

09-25.title: First Demonstration of Remote Control
09-25.description: On September 25, 1906, Leonardo Torres Quevedo successfully demonstrated the Telekino by guiding a boat from shore, considered the birth of remote control.

09-25.title: Henry Ford Announces 8-Hour, 5-Day Workweek
09-25.description: On September 25, 1926, Henry Ford announced an 8-hour, 5-day workweek for workers at the Ford Motor Company.

09-25.title: Sandra Day O'Connor Becomes First Female Supreme Court Justice
09-25.description: On September 25, 1981, Sandra Day O'Connor was sworn in as the first female U.S. Supreme Court Justice.

09-26.title: Francis Drake Completes Circumnavigation
09-26.description: On September 26, 1580, Francis Drake completed his circumnavigation of the world, sailing into Plymouth, England aboard the Golden Hind.

09-26.title: Parthenon Damaged in Attack
09-26.description: On September 26, 1687, the Acropolis in Athens was attacked by the Venetian army, damaging the Parthenon.

09-26.title: Amsterdam Supports 'The Glorious Revolution'
09-26.description: On September 26, 1688, the city council of Amsterdam voted to support Prince William of Orange's invasion of England, known as 'The Glorious Revolution'.

09-26.title: Holy Alliance Signed
09-26.description: On September 26, 1815, Russia, Prussia, and Austria signed the Holy Alliance to uphold Christian principles and monarchy in Europe.

09-26.title: United Kingdom Annexes Ashanti Kingdom
09-26.description: On September 26, 1901, the United Kingdom annexed the Ashanti Kingdom and placed it under the governor of the Gold Coast (now Ghana).

09-26.title: Einstein's Special Theory of Relativity Published
09-26.description: On September 26, 1905, the physics journal Annalen der Physik published Albert Einstein's paper 'On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies,' which introduced his special theory of relativity.

09-26.title: Meuse-Argonne Offensive Begins
09-26.description: On September 26, 1918, the Meuse-Argonne Offensive began, the largest and most costly American offensive of World War I.

09-27.title: William the Conqueror Sails to Invade England
09-27.description: On September 27, 1066, William the Conqueror's troops set sail from Normandy to invade England.

09-27.title: Deadly Earthquake Near China
09-27.description: On September 27, 1290, an earthquake in the Gulf of Chihli (Bohai Sea) near China reportedly killed 100,000 people.

09-27.title: John Adams Appointed to Negotiate Peace
09-27.description: On September 27, 1779, John Adams was appointed by the Continental Congress to negotiate Revolutionary War peace terms with Great Britain.

09-27.title: Mexican War of Independence Ends
09-27.description: On September 27, 1821, Mexican revolutionary forces occupied Mexico City as the Spanish withdrew, bringing an end to the Mexican War of Independence.

09-27.title: Egyptian Hieroglyphs Deciphered
09-27.description: On September 27, 1822, French scholar Jean-François Champollion announced he had deciphered Egyptian hieroglyphs using the Rosetta Stone.

09-27.title: First Head of State of Modern Greece Assassinated
09-27.description: On September 27, 1831, Ioannis Kapodistrias, the first Head of State of modern Greece, was assassinated in Nafplion.

09-27.title: First Ford Model T Leaves Factory
09-27.description: On September 27, 1908, Henry Ford's first Ford Model T automobile left the Piquette Avenue Plant in Detroit, Michigan.

09-28.title: Saint Wenceslas Murdered
09-28.description: On September 28, 935, Saint Wenceslas, Duke of Bohemia, was murdered by his brother Boleslaus I.

09-28.title: Norman Conquest of England Begins
09-28.description: On September 28, 1066, William the Conqueror landed at Pevensey Bay in Sussex, beginning the Norman Conquest of England.

09-28.title: Siege of Yorktown Begins
09-28.description: On September 28, 1781, American and French troops began the Siege of Yorktown against British forces.

09-28.title: Yellow River Flood Kills Millions
09-28.description: On September 28, 1887, the Yellow River (Huáng Hé) flooded in China, killing between 900,000 and 2 million people.

09-28.title: German–Soviet Boundary and Friendship Treaty Signed
09-28.description: On September 28, 1939, Germany and the Soviet Union signed a treaty that redrew their spheres of influence in central Europe.

09-29.title: Darius I Secures Persian Throne
09-29.description: On September 29, 522 BC, Darius I of Persia killed the usurper Gaumâta, securing his position as king of the Persian Empire.

09-29.title: Battle of Salamis
09-29.description: On September 29, 480 BC, the Greek fleet under Themistocles defeated the Persian fleet under Xerxes I at the Battle of Salamis.

09-29.title: French Wars of Religion Break Out
09-29.description: On September 29, 1567, a War of Religion broke out in France as Huguenots tried to kidnap King Charles IX.

09-29.title: London's 'Bobbies' Appear on Streets
09-29.description: On September 29, 1829, the first units of the London Metropolitan Police, known as 'Bobbies,' appeared on the streets of the capital.

09-29.title: 2008 Financial Crisis: Dow Jones Plummets
09-29.description: On September 29, 2008, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 777.68 points, its largest single-day point loss at the time.

09-30.title: Suleiman the Magnificent Becomes Ottoman Sultan
09-30.description: On September 30, 1520, Suleiman the Magnificent succeeded his father, Selim I, as Ottoman Sultan.

09-30.title: First Use of Anesthetic Ether
09-30.description: On September 30, 1846, anesthetic ether was used for the first time in a dental procedure by American dentist Dr. William Morton.

09-30.title: Bismarck's 'Blood and Iron' Speech
09-30.description: On September 30, 1862, Prussian Minister-President Otto von Bismarck delivered his famous 'Blood and Iron' speech on the unification of German territories.

09-30.title: Munich Agreement Signed
09-30.description: On September 30, 1938, the Munich Agreement was signed by Germany, Italy, France, and Britain, forcing Czechoslovakia to cede territory to Germany.

09-30.title: Nuremberg Trials Verdicts Delivered
09-30.description: On September 30, 1946, twenty-two Nazi leaders were found guilty of war crimes at the Nuremberg trials.

09-30.title: Ethernet Specifications Published
09-30.description: On September 30, 1980, Ethernet specifications were published by Xerox in collaboration with Intel and Digital Equipment Corporation.

10-01.title: Battle of Gaugamela
10-01.description: On October 1, 331 BC, Alexander the Great defeated Darius III of Persia in the Battle of Gaugamela.

10-01.title: William of Orange Accepts British Crown Invitation
10-01.description: On October 1, 1688, Prince William of Orange accepted an invitation to take up the British crown, leading to the Glorious Revolution.

10-01.title: Congress of Vienna Opens
10-01.description: On October 1, 1814, the Congress of Vienna opened to redraw Europe's political map after the defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte.

10-01.title: Karl Marx Publishes 'Das Kapital'
10-01.description: On October 1, 1867, Karl Marx published 'Das Kapital' in Berlin, a foundational text of communist theory.

10-01.title: Ford Introduces the Model T
10-01.description: On October 1, 1908, Henry Ford introduced the Model T car, priced at $825.

10-01.title: Arab and British Forces Capture Damascus
10-01.description: On October 1, 1918, during World War I, a combined Arab and British force, including Lawrence of Arabia, captured Damascus from the Ottoman Empire.

10-01.title: Gorbachev Becomes Soviet Head of State
10-01.description: On October 1, 1988, Mikhail Gorbachev became Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, effectively the head of state of the Soviet Union.

10-02.title: Saladin Captures Jerusalem
10-02.description: On October 2, 1187, Sultan Saladin captured Jerusalem from the Crusaders.

10-02.title: King Henry VII of England Invades France
10-02.description: On October 2, 1492, King Henry VII of England invaded France.

10-02.title: Washington Transmits Bill of Rights to States
10-02.description: On October 2, 1789, George Washington transmitted the proposed constitutional amendments, known as the Bill of Rights, to the states for ratification.

10-02.title: Opus Dei Founded
10-02.description: On October 2, 1928, Opus Dei was founded by Catholic priest Josemaría Escrivá in Madrid, Spain.

10-02.title: Warsaw Uprising Ends
10-02.description: On October 2, 1944, Polish resistance fighters capitulated in the Warsaw Uprising after an estimated 250,000 people were killed.

10-02.title: Second Inter-Korean Summit
10-02.description: On October 2, 2007, President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea walked across the Military Demarcation Line for the second Inter-Korean Summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il.

10-03.title: Legendary Founding of Gojoseon (Korea)
10-03.description: On October 3, 2333 BC, according to legend, the state of Gojoseon (modern-day Korea) was founded by Dangun Wanggeom.

10-03.title: Vercingetorix Surrenders to Caesar
10-03.description: On October 3, 52 BC, Vercingetorix, leader of the Gauls, surrendered to the Romans under Julius Caesar, ending the Battle of Alesia.

10-03.title: First Execution by Hanging, Drawing, and Quartering
10-03.description: On October 3, 1283, Dafydd ap Gruffydd, Prince of Gwynedd, Wales, became the first person known to be executed by being hanged, drawn, and quartered.

10-03.title: First Facsimile Photo Sent Over Telephone Lines
10-03.description: On October 3, 1922, the first facsimile photo was sent over city telephone lines in Washington, D.C.

10-03.title: Italy Invades Ethiopia
10-03.description: On October 3, 1935, Italy invaded Ethiopia, starting the Second Italo-Ethiopian War.

10-03.title: German Reunification
10-03.description: On October 3, 1990, the reunification of East and West Germany was formally completed.

10-04.title: First Complete English Bible Printed
10-04.description: On October 4, 1535, the first complete English-language Bible, the 'Coverdale Bible,' was printed, with translations by Myles Coverdale.

10-04.title: Last Julian Calendar Day in Catholic Europe
10-04.description: On October 4, 1582, this was the last Julian calendar day in Spain, Portugal, and the Papal States. To sync to the new Gregorian calendar, 10 days were skipped, and the next day was October 15.

10-04.title: The Orient Express's First Journey
10-04.description: On October 4, 1883, the Orient Express departed on its first official journey from Paris to Istanbul.

10-04.title: Ashanti Uprising Ends
10-04.description: On October 4, 1900, around 4,000 Ashantis were defeated by the British in the Gold Coast (Ghana), ending the War of the Golden Stool.

10-04.title: Soviet Union Launches Sputnik I
10-04.description: On October 4, 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik I, the first artificial Earth satellite, into orbit.

10-04.title: Russian Constitutional Crisis
10-04.description: On October 4, 1993, troops and tanks under President Boris Yeltsin shelled and occupied the Russian White House in Moscow to end a constitutional crisis.

10-04.title: Kevin McCarthy Ousted as U.S. House Speaker
10-04.description: On October 4, 2023, Kevin McCarthy became the first Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives to be removed from office.

10-05.title: First Mongol Invasion of Japan
10-05.description: On October 5, 1274, soldiers of the Mongol army landed on the Japanese island of Tsushima in the first attack of Kublai Khan's Mongol invasion of Japan.

10-05.title: Women's March on Versailles
10-05.description: On October 5, 1789, women of Paris marched to Versailles to confront King Louis XVI, demanding bread and his return to Paris.

10-05.title: Battle of the Thames
10-05.description: On October 5, 1813, American forces under General William Henry Harrison defeated Tecumseh's Confederacy and their British allies at the Battle of the Thames.

10-05.title: Calcutta Cyclone
